a rat (= an animal like a large mouse) that is used in a scientific experiment:
examples: At very high levels, the chemical has killed lab rats who breathed it.

meanings.definition: a person or thing that is used as part of a scientific experiment or to test something new:
examples: She felt the medical profession had used her mother as a lab rat.

meanings.definition: produced artificially by scientists, rather than formed naturally:
examples: Lab-grown meat is being developed so people can eat flesh without eating animals.

meanings.definition: a system for writing down ballet movements (= a type of dancing where carefully organized movements tell a story or express an idea):

meanings.definition: a piece of paper or other material that gives you information about the object it is attached to:
examples: Remember to put some address labels on the suitcases.

meanings.definition: a word or a phrase that is used to describe the characteristics or qualities of people, activities, or things, often in a way that is unfair:
examples: He seems to be stuck with the label of "troublemaker".

meanings.definition: a company that produces goods for sale, the goods themselves, or the company's name or symbol:
examples: Her favourite designer label (= maker of expensive clothes) is Armani.

The group have just signed (= arranged to record) with a new record label.

meanings.definition: to fasten a label to:
examples: The parcel was clearly labelled "Fragile".

meanings.definition: a piece of paper or other material that gives information about the object it is attached to:

meanings.definition: A label can also mean the name or symbol of a company that produces goods for sale:
examples: Everything we produce goes out under our own label.

meanings.definition: A label can also be a name or a phrase used to describe the characteristics or qualities of people, activities, or things:
examples: It’s hard to say whether to apply the label “jazz” or “rock” to her music.

meanings.definition: to attach a piece of paper or other material that has information about an object to that object:

meanings.definition: To label something or someone is also to name that thing’s or person’s character:

meanings.definition: a piece of paper or other material that gives you information about the object that it is fixed to:

(the person or thing) after everyone or everything else:
examples: I hate being the last one to arrive at a meeting.

I know Johnson finished last in the race, but who was second to last (= the one before the one at the end)?

meanings.definition: (being) the only one or part that is left:
examples: Do you mind if I have the last chocolate?
I'm down to my last dollar - could I borrow some money for lunch?

meanings.definition: (being) the most recent or the one before the present one:

Could you account for your whereabouts on Sunday last?
The/These last five years have been very difficult for him.

Each of her paintings has been better than the last.

meanings.definition: to continue to exist:
examples: The meeting lasted two hours.
The drought lasted for several months.
They say the snow will last until the end of next week.
I can't see the ceasefire lasting.
They haven't had an argument for two weeks, but it's too good to last (= they'll have an argument soon).

meanings.definition: to continue being good or suitable:
examples: There's no point buying something that isn't going to last.

meanings.definition: the person or thing after everyone or everything else:

meanings.definition: the only one or part that is left:

meanings.definition: the most recent, or the one before the present one:

meanings.definition: being the least desirable or least likely:

meanings.definition: to continue for a period of time, or to continue to exist:

meanings.definition: To last is also to continue in a situation although it is difficult:

meanings.definition: To last is also to continue to work well or stay in good condition:

meanings.definition: (coming) after everyone or everything else:

meanings.definition: no longer alive, esp. having recently died:

meanings.definition: someone who starts using a new product, especially a new piece of technology, later than many other people :

meanings.definition: a person who buys a new type of product or service after many others have already started using it:

meanings.definition: someone who becomes good at something after people usually become good at it:

meanings.definition: someone who becomes good at something after people usually become good at it:

meanings.definition: too late to be useful:

meanings.definition: the large group of workers in an organization who start to use new methods, systems, etc. only after others have already done so:

meanings.definition: happening very late in the evening or at night:

meanings.definition: recently:

meanings.definition: the fact of being present but needing particular conditions to become active, obvious, or completely developed:

meanings.definition: the delay between an instruction to transfer (= move) computer information and the information being transferred, for example over the internet:

meanings.definition: the fact of happening or arriving after the planned, expected, usual, or necessary time:

meanings.definition: the fact of being near the end of the day:

meanings.definition: present but needing particular conditions to become active, obvious, or completely developed:

meanings.definition: present, but not yet active, developed, or obvious:

meanings.definition: present, but not yet active, developed, or obvious:

meanings.definition: demand for a product or service that a consumer cannot satisfy because they do not have enough money, because the product or service is not available, or because they do not know that it is available:
examples: New facilities were built just because the funds were there, rather than to fulfil any latent demand.

meanings.definition: happening at a time in the future, or after the time you have mentioned:

meanings.definition: at a time in the future, or after the time you have mentioned:

meanings.definition: at the same level in an organization or between two different organizations:
examples: Susan's lateral move to do the same job at a competitor meant better benefits and more pay.
We've made a number of important lateral hires from quality firms.

meanings.definition: a small medical device that tests whether or not there is a particular substance, gene, etc. in a sample:
examples: The company has become a major producer of lateral flow tests, the most familiar being "blue-strip" pregnancy tests.
Schools will be offered rapid Covid-19 tests using lateral flow devices.

meanings.definition: a test done using a small medical device that tests whether or not there is a particular substance, gene, etc. in a sample:
examples: I've just had my first lateral flow test.
Your coronavirus lateral flow test result is negative.

meanings.definition: one of two parts on either side of the brain where nerves from the eye connect to the thalamus (= the part of the brain that controls the senses) :
examples: Neurons in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus play a pivotal role in visual processing.
The optic tracts terminate in the lateral geniculate nuclei.
The visual pathway extends from the retina through the optic nerve, then the optic chiasm, through the optic tract, and the lateral geniculate body.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         horizontal integration  :
examples: The lateral integration of media interests has created a new environment for advertising.
Lateral amalgamation between three operating steel companies was justified.

meanings.definition: in American football, rugby, and other sports, a pass (= throw) that is made to a player who is standing behind or to the side of the player throwing the ball while that player is facing the opponent's goal:
examples: The quarterback threw a lateral to the running back, who looked for an opening to gain extra yards.
Once you are past the line of scrimmage, you can only make lateral passes to other players.
The receiver caught a lateral from the quarterback, who had already gone past the line of scrimmage.

meanings.definition: a way of solving a problem by thinking about it in a different and original way and not using traditional or expected methods
the process of considering a problem in a different and original way, rather than following traditional or expected ideas:
examples: After a little lateral thinking, we solved the problem by starting again.

meanings.definition: either of two C-shaped ventricles (= spaces), one on each side of the brain, that contains cerebrospinal fluid (= liquid that moves around the brain and spinal cord):
examples: CT findings showed that the cyst originated from the right lateral ventricle.
This blocks the normal flow of the cerebral spinal fluid from the lateral ventricles into the third ventricle.

meanings.definition: a Latin word meaning "lateral" (= relating to the sides of an object or to sideways movement), used in medical names and descriptions
towards the side
in a direction away from the midline:
examples: a laterally spreading tumour

meanings.definition: with the flow of air blocked in the middle, so that the air flows to the side:
examples: The sound /l/ is produced laterally.

meanings.definition: a type of reddish clay soil containing iron and aluminium, found especially in tropical areas
the process by which rock becomes laterite (= a type of reddish clay soil containing iron and aluminium, found especially in tropical areas):
examples: The region's soils are mainly derived from basalt that has undergone mild laterization.
an episode of emersion and laterization

meanings.definition: newest or most recent or modern:

the latest fashions

meanings.definition: newest, most recent, or most modern:
examples: Did you see her latest movie?

meanings.definition: the most recent news:

meanings.definition: a white liquid produced by many plants, especially rubber trees, or a rubber-like substance made from this or from plastic, used in making clothes, paint, glue, etc.:

a pair of latex surgical gloves

meanings.definition: a white liquid produced by particular plants, esp. rubber trees, or an artificial substance similar to this, used esp. in paint, glue, and cloth:
examples: latex paint
latex gloves

a machine for changing the shape of a piece of wood, metal, etc. that works by turning the material while a sharp tool is pressed against it
a pale, usually white, mass of small bubbles produced especially when soap is mixed with water:

an occasion when a large group of police run forward in an attacking movement carrying their sticks
the language used by ancient Romans and as the language of educated people in many European countries in the past
written in Latin:

meanings.definition: relating to (people or things in) countries that use a language that developed from Latin, such as French or Spanish:
examples: his Latin good looks

meanings.definition: the areas of North, South, and Central America where Spanish or Portuguese is spoken
from or relating to the areas of North, South, and Central America where Spanish or Portuguese is spoken
a person of or coming from South America, Central America, or Mexico
a person who studies or is an expert on Latin America:
examples: As a Latin Americanist I should have been able to make a living in Mexico.
The dictionary is a tremendous achievement and of special interest to Latin Americans and the Latin Americanist academic community.

meanings.definition: a writing system based on the Latin alphabet:
examples: Indonesian is an Asian language with a simple grammar and Latin script.
Ataturk decided to move from Arabic to Latin script.

meanings.definition: a woman or girl who lives in the US and who comes from, or whose family comes from, Latin America:
examples: His father was black, his mother a Latina.

meanings.definition: (of a woman or girl) from or connected with the countries of Latin America, or having parents or grandparents from these countries:
examples: My Latina mother-in-law cooks the best traditional Mexican food around.
She became the first Latina member of the council.

meanings.definition: a woman who lives in the US whose family is from Latin America, or a woman who lives in Latin America:
examples: a Latina activist
He appointed a Latina to the education committee.

meanings.definition: the process of making a word or your speech more similar to Latin, the language used by ancient Romans and as a language of educated people in many European countries in the past, or a word that is made similar to a Latin word:
examples: Features that are characteristic of his prose style include wordiness, Latinization (e. g. using "demise" rather than "death"), and frequent use of archaic forms.
Murray refused to include the word "appendicitis" in the dictionary, criticizing ugly Latinisations of words by the medical profession.

meanings.definition: the process of starting to write a language or words using the Roman alphabet, the alphabet used for writing most western European languages including English:
examples: The spread of Russian in the region was assisted by the difficulties experienced in Latinization of local alphabets.
He strongly objected to the colonial orthographic Latinisation of Kiswahili.

meanings.definition: the process of making something more similar to or typical of ancient Roman or Latin styles, beliefs, customs, etc.:
examples: The opening chapters of the book describe the Latinization of Gaul.

meanings.definition: the process of becoming more influenced by the cultures and languages of Latin America, the areas of North, South, and Central America where Spanish or Portuguese is spoken, for example because of having a large number of people originally from those areas:
examples: Latinization is driving bigger sales of Latino-influenced drinks in the wider market.
The San Francisco Jazz Festival will also celebrate the Latinization of California culture.
We have seen the Latinisation of fast food menus, which now feature Cuban sandwiches and pineapple mango dipping sauce for chicken nuggets.

meanings.definition: the process of making music more similar to styles of music originally from Latin America:
examples: Critics remarked on the growing Latinisation of their sound.

meanings.definition: to make a word or your speech more similar to Latin, the language used by ancient Romans and as a language of educated people in many European countries in the past:
examples: Linnaeus was fluent and literate in Latin, and he Latinized his own name from Lin.

meanings.definition: to start writing a language or words using the Roman alphabet, the alphabet used for writing most western European languages including English:
examples: As part of Ataturk's drive to Westernize and secularize Turkey, he Latinised its script.

meanings.definition: to make something more similar to or typical of ancient Roman or Latin styles, beliefs, customs, etc.:
examples: The Romans adapted and Latinised the Greek forms of ornament, Doric, Ionic and Corinthian.
The Latins divided the Byzantine Empire amongst themselves and tried unsuccessfully to Latinise Eastern Christians.

meanings.definition: to make something more influenced by the cultures and languages of Latin America, the areas of North, South, and Central America where Spanish or Portuguese is spoken, for example because of having a large number of people originally from those areas:
examples: They are planning to use dulce de leche and other flavourings to Latinise their range of ice creams.
The growing popularity of the quinceañera is a good example of the Latinizing of American culture.

meanings.definition: to make music more similar to styles of music originally from Latin America:
examples: She energetically Latinised many of the numbers that she sang, even the sumptuous waltz "Lover".

meanings.definition: (of a word) made more similar to Latin, the language used by ancient Romans and as a language of educated people in many European countries in the past:
examples: The scientific name of the snowy owl is Nyctea scandiaca, "scandiaca" being a Latinized word referring to Scandinavia.
Many borrowed French words originated in Latin, and some became Latinised in their spelling when they entered English.

meanings.definition: (of a language or words) written in the Roman alphabet, the alphabet used for writing most western European languages including English:
examples: Like Hebrew, Arabic reads from right to left, and its graceful script bears no resemblance to the Latinized lettering of the Western world.
There was a proposal for the language to become fully Latinised, but this was reversed, leaving Cyrillic the only official script.

meanings.definition: made more similar to or typical of ancient Roman or Latin styles, customs, beliefs, etc.:
examples: It is believed that the Etruscans becane gradually more Latinized under Roman rule.

meanings.definition: influenced by the cultures and languages of Latin America, the areas of North, South, and Central America where Spanish or Portuguese is spoken, for example because of having a large number of people originally from those areas:
examples: It is the most Latinized city in the county, with Hispanics making up 30 per cent of its residents.

meanings.definition: influenced by or similar to styles of music originally from Latin America:
examples: Their music is a punchy combination of Latinized rock, jazz and funk.
He did a Latinised cover of "Every Day I Have The Blues".

meanings.definition: someone who lives in the US and who comes from, or whose family comes from, Latin America:
examples: Latinos are the fastest-growing minority in the US.
The appointment of Gonzales marked the first time a Latino had served as attorney general.

meanings.definition: from or connected with the countries of Latin America, or having parents or grandparents from these countries:
examples: Educational materials will also include Latino content.
She is involved in a new community program to help Latino families with language barriers at home.

meanings.definition: a person who lives in the US whose family is from Latin America, or a person who lives in Latin America:
examples: a Latino leader
Small farming towns that were largely Anglo for more than 100 years are now as much as 98 percent Latino.

meanings.definition: from Latin America, or having a family from Latin America; used when you do not want to say if the person is a man or a woman:
examples: A Latinx immigrant student on the border of Texas and Mexico may have a different experience than a Latinx immigrant student in North Carolina.

meanings.definition: a person who lives in the US and who comes from, or whose family comes from, Latin America; used when you do not want to say that the person is a man or a woman:
examples: Some companies in El Paso, Texas seek out Spanish-speaking employees that can communicate with US Latinxs.

meanings.definition: to smile while making sounds with your voice that show you think something is funny or you are happy:
examples: They laughed at her jokes.
I couldn't stop laughing.
I said he'd have to give a talk and he laughed nervously.
She's so funny - she really makes me laugh.
It's very rare that a book is so good you actually laugh out loud.
It was so funny, I burst out laughing (= laughed suddenly and loudly).
I laughed till I cried.

meanings.definition: the act or sound of laughing:
examples: a loud/nervous laugh
I was embarrassed at the time, but I had a good laugh about it later.

meanings.definition: an enjoyable or funny activity:
examples: "How was the party?" "Oh, it was a laugh."

meanings.definition: someone who is funny:
examples: You'd like Sharon - she's a good laugh.

meanings.definition: to make the sounds and movements of the face and body that express happiness or amusement, or that sometimes express ridicule or anxiety:
examples: The audience just laughed and laughed.
That guy always makes me laugh.
When I made a face at Drew, he laughed out loud.
We were laughing at the clown.

meanings.definition: Sometimes when you laugh at someone, you are ridiculing that person:
examples: I don’t want to be laughed at by my classmates.

meanings.definition: the sounds and movements of the face and body that express happiness or amusement, or that sometimes express ridicule or anxiety:
examples: Holly has a very strange laugh – it sounds like she’s screaming.

meanings.definition: infml A laugh is also an amusing or ridiculous situation or person:
examples: You should have seen Sean trying to stay on the skateboard – what a laugh!

meanings.definition: to show that you think someone or something is stupid:
examples: I can't go into work looking like this - everyone will laugh at me.

meanings.definition: to treat someone or something as if they are not important or do not deserve serious attention:
examples: If you say that, people will just laugh at you.

meanings.definition: to make it obvious to someone that you do not respect them:
examples: They'd laugh in your face if you suggested me for the post.

meanings.definition: to laugh a lot, very loudly

laugh-out-of-the-other-side-of-mouth.name: laugh out of the other side of your mouth

meanings.definition: used to tell someone that, despite being pleased now, they will not be pleased later when things do not happen as expected or planned:
examples: She's pleased with her promotion but she'll laugh out of the other side of her mouth when she sees the extra work.

meanings.definition: to make yourself laugh about something unpleasant in order to make it seem less important or serious:
examples: She tried to laugh off their remarks, but I could see she was hurt.

meanings.definition: to pretend that something is less serious than it is:
examples: The coach laughed off the idea that his team wasn't ready to play.

meanings.definition: to secretly find something funny:

meanings.definition: to laugh a lot, loudly:

meanings.definition: in a way that makes you laugh so that other people can hear you:

meanings.definition: silly and not deserving to be seriously considered:

meanings.definition: to put away or stop using something:
examples: Lay down your weapons and surrender.

meanings.definition: to state something plainly esp. as an official rule:
examples: The coach laid down the rules from the first day of practice.

meanings.definition: to officially establish a rule, or to officially state the way in which something should be done:
examples: This is in line with the policy laid down by the management.

New managers tend to lay down the law and demand total compliance with their wishes.

meanings.definition: to get a supply of something because you will probably need it in the future:
examples: We'd better lay in plenty of food in case we're cut off when it snows.

meanings.definition: in basketball, to jump in the air near the basket and drop the ball into the net with one hand to score:
examples: They'd get a rebound or a loose ball and lay it in.

meanings.definition: in basketball, an action in which a player jumps in the air very close to the basket and drops the ball into the net with one hand to score:
examples: His lay-in with 11 minutes left in the fourth quarter gave Boston a 30-point lead.
Brown scored on layins, crossovers, and short flip shots.

meanings.definition: to obtain and store something for later use:
examples: We’d better lay in plenty of food for the winter months.

meanings.definition: to provide something for a group of people:
examples: They lay on free entertainment at the club every day.

meanings.definition: to tell someone something they did not know:
examples: I hate to be the one to lay this on you, but your girlfriend has just left with another guy.

meanings.definition: to risk harm to something: to say very clearly that something is the case:
examples: I'd be laying my career/life on the line by giving you that information.
You're just going to have to lay it on the line and tell her that her work's not good enough.

meanings.definition: to arrange something on a flat surface:
examples: Most of Manhattan is laid out in/on a grid pattern.

meanings.definition: to spend money, especially a large amount:
examples: It's not every day you lay out $500 on a dress.

meanings.definition: to explain something clearly, usually in writing:

meanings.definition: to prepare a dead person's body to be buried
to hit someone so hard that they fall down and become unconscious:
examples: Harrison was laid out for several minutes by a blow to the head.

meanings.definition: to arrange in a pattern or design; to plan something by showing how its parts fit together:
examples: The designer laid out the book with pictures on every page.

meanings.definition: to spend money, esp. if it seems like a large amount:
examples: He has laid out $40,000 to fund Little League teams in California.

meanings.definition: to explain or describe something in a clear and detailed way:
examples: Our social media approach was laid out in the agenda.
He didn't understand that I was firing him, so I laid it out for him.

meanings.definition: to design or arrange something in a useful way:
examples: We laid out the web page so that the links were more clearly visible.

meanings.definition: to produce the basic ideas or structures from which something much larger develops:
examples: The two leaders have laid the foundations of a new era in cooperation between their countries.

lay-the-ghost-of-to-rest.name: lay the ghost of something (to rest)

meanings.definition: to finally stop being worried or upset about something that has worried or upset you for a long time:
examples: With one stunning performance, he has laid to rest the ghost of all his defeats last season.

meanings.definition: to prepare for or start an activity or task:
examples: This study lays the groundwork for understanding the nature of different mutations of the disease.

meanings.definition: to do something that will cause you trouble in the future:
examples: You're laying up trouble for yourself if you ignore health problems now.

lay-open-to-attack-criticism-ridicule-et.name: lay yourself open to attack, criticism, ridicule, etc.

meanings.definition: a place at the side of a road where a vehicle can stop for a short time without interrupting other traffic:

meanings.definition: to control a group of people, a country, or a situation:
examples: I think we've chosen the right person to lead the expedition.

meanings.definition: (especially in sports or other competitions) to be in front, to be first, or to be winning:
examples: After 30 minutes the challengers were leading by two goals.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to do something, especially something bad:
examples: The brochure led me to believe that the price included home delivery.

meanings.definition: to show the way to a group of people, animals, vehicles, etc. by going in front of them:
examples: I don't know the way, so you'd better lead.

meanings.definition: To lead a group of moving people or vehicles is to walk or drive in front of them:

meanings.definition: to take someone somewhere, by going with them:
examples: She led them down the hall.

meanings.definition: to take hold of a person or animal and take him, her, or it somewhere:
examples: She took the child by the hand and led him upstairs to bed.

meanings.definition: (especially of roads, paths, doors, signs, information, etc.) to go in a particular direction or have a particular result, or to allow or cause this:
examples: There's a track that leads directly to the reservoir.

meanings.definition: in sports and activities, to move forward first with a particular part of your body, especially as a habit:

meanings.definition: in boxing, to make a first attacking punch (= hit), especially with a particular hand:

meanings.definition: a winning position during a race or other situation where people are competing:

meanings.definition: the act of showing a person or group of people what to do:

meanings.definition: a piece of information that allows a discovery to be made or a solution to be found:

meanings.definition: to prepare the way for something to happen; cause:

meanings.definition: (esp. in sports or other competitions) to be in front, be first, or be winning:

meanings.definition: a piece of information that allows a discovery to be made or a solution to be found:

meanings.definition: a dense, soft, dark gray metal, used esp. in combination with other metals and in batteries (= devices that produce electricity):

meanings.definition: the black writing material made of graphite, used esp. in the center of a pencil
to be in charge of a group of people, an organization, or a situation:
examples: They led a management buy-out of the business, raising €10m in capital.

meanings.definition: to be in front, be first, or be winning in a particular situation or area of business:
examples: German, Swiss, and Scandinavian banks lead the internet-based financial services market in Europe.

meanings.definition: to happen before something else happens:

meanings.definition: to influence someone to do something:

meanings.definition: an action or example that shows a person or group what to do:

meanings.definition: a piece of information that allows a discovery to be made, customers to be found, or a solution to be found:

meanings.definition: most important among a group of people, products, etc.:
examples: The company's lead product for lung and certain blood cancers is in Phase II trials in humans.

meanings.definition: to be better than all other people or things:

meanings.definition: to make more progress than other people in the development of something:

meanings.definition: the time between the design of a product and its production, or between ordering a product and receiving it

meanings.definition: If an action or event leads to something, it causes that thing to happen or exist:
examples: Reducing speed limits should lead to fewer deaths on the roads.

meanings.definition: if an action or event leads to something, it makes that thing happen or exist:
examples: Higher demand for goods and services leads to higher imports from abroad.

meanings.definition:
→

If a period of time or series of events leads up to an event or activity, it happens until that event or activity begins:
examples: The pilot had no recollection of the events leading up to the crash.

meanings.definition: to prepare to talk about something by gradually mentioning the subject you want to talk about:
examples: He started telling me about a wonderful new restaurant he'd been to and I wondered what he was leading up to.

meanings.definition: to happen, say, or do in preparation for something:
examples: In the three games leading up to the Sugar Bowl, his team yielded 35, 35, and 42 points.
I thought you were leading up to a question at the end of that.

meanings.definition: if a period of time or series of events leads up to an event or activity, it continues until that event or activity begins:
examples: The document provides a window into events that led up to the sale of the corporation.

meanings.definition: one of the first people or organizations to use a new method, product, etc.:
examples: Lead users are valued not only as early adopters but as sources of new product ideas.

meanings.definition: to put a particular story first or in the most important position in a news report or newspaper:
examples: The Times leads with the coming mayoral elections.

meanings.definition: to put a particular story first or in the most important position in a news report or newspaper:
examples: The Times leads with the coming mayoral elections.

meanings.definition: something that introduces something else, such as the words and music that are used to introduce a television programme
to be very lucky in life, often escaping dangerous situations without being hurt:
examples: For many years, he led a charmed life, working on movie projects all over the world.

She was a popular society girl, leading a charmed life.
By all accounts, they lived a charmed life, with luxurious homes in Boston and Paris.
Rudi lived a charmed life, making friends wherever he went.

meanings.definition: to live an easy and comfortable life, without any need to work hard

dark grey:

meanings.definition: without energy or feeling:

meanings.definition: like lead in color or weight; gray or heavy:
examples: They said goodbye under a leaden sky.

meanings.definition: in a way that lacks energy and feeling:
examples: At times he could be leadenly solemn.
Her stories are leadenly described as "often quite amusing".

meanings.definition: a person in control of a group, country, or situation:
examples: a religious leader

He's a natural leader.
She was elected as leader of the campaign group.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is winning during a race or other situation where people are competing:
examples: He's fallen two laps behind the leaders.

a person who manages or controls other people, esp. because of his or her ability or position:

meanings.definition: someone or something that is the first or the most important:
examples: Her company is a leader in the women’s clothing industry.

meanings.definition: a company, product, etc. that has higher sales than its competitors:
examples: The brand is market leader in France, where it has a 49% market share.

meanings.definition: a person who is in charge of a group, country, situation, etc.:
examples: Union leaders said they expect up to 40,000 of the 47,000 workers at the plant to stop work.

meanings.definition: a board or list showing the names and scores of those who are doing best in a game, competition, etc.:
examples: The golfer blasted his way to the top of the leaderboard.

meanings.definition: having no leader or person in charge:
examples: His death left the Alliance leaderless at a crucial moment.

meanings.definition: the set of characteristics that make a good leader:

meanings.definition: the position or fact of being the leader:
examples: The group flourished under her firm leadership.

meanings.definition: the quality or ability that makes a person a leader, or the position of being a leader:
examples: The company was extremely successful under Murphy’s leadership.

meanings.definition: Leadership is also the people who are in charge of a government or group:
examples: the Democratic leadership in Congress

meanings.definition: the position or fact of being a leader:

a leadership role/style/team
business/corporate/executive leadership

meanings.definition: the set of characteristics that makes a good leader:

leadership qualities/skills

meanings.definition: the position of being a company, product, etc. that is more successful than its competitors:
examples: Our people are working together to attain leadership in customer service, quality and financial returns.

meanings.definition: very important or most important:

the world's leading manufacturer of audio equipment

meanings.definition: the lead (= type of metal) used to cover (parts of) a roof
first or most important:
examples: She is a leading expert on the art of ancient Greece.

meanings.definition: best, most important, or most successful:
examples: The cereal is sold under several leading brand names.

meanings.definition:
an

a type of product made by a particular company and sold under a particular name that sells more than other similar products:

meanings.definition: a question or problem that is decided in a court of law, which is used as an example to decide similar cases:
examples: The leading case on liability for negligent advice, referred to as negligent misstatement, is Hedley Byrne & Co.

meanings.definition: the most advanced position in an area of activity:

meanings.definition: the most advanced position in a particular activity:

meanings.definition: having the most advanced position in a particular activity:

meanings.definition: the most experienced person in a factory, etc.
something that shows what a situation will be like in the future rather than showing what it is like now or has been like in previous weeks, months, etc.:
examples: Claims for unemployment insurance, a leading indicator for the economy, rose in July.

meanings.definition: a measure that is used to predict future financial and economic activity, because it changes before the economy of a country has changed:
examples: Leading indicators and current conditions point to further declines in capital spending.
The Dow Jones Index is often seen as a reflection of the economy and a leading indicator of where stocks are headed.

meanings.definition: the female actor who has the most important part in a play or film
an important and respected person in a group or organization:

meanings.definition: the actor who has the most important part in a play or film
a note that is the seventh note of a diatonic scale (= a musical scale that is either major or minor):
examples: Pentatonic scales have no semitones, and no leading note to pull towards the tonic.

meanings.definition: a question that tricks someone into answering in a particular way
a note that is the seventh note of a diatonic scale, one semitone below the tonic:
examples: Both the major and minor scales include a leading tone.
The trombone is anchored closely to the harmonic progression and outlines its main notes and leading tones.

meanings.definition: increases or reductions in the speed at which something happens, for example in the payment of money or the time in which a piece of work is completed :
examples: The CBI's chief economic adviser said the leads and lags in getting the spending plans through Whitehall could delay implementation.
Firms use leads and lags in foreign trade when a currency is expected to move in one direction or the other.

meanings.definition: one of the flat, usually green parts of a plant that are joined at one end to the stem or branch:

autumn leaves

meanings.definition: a thin sheet of paper
an extra part of a table that can be folded away when not being used
any of the flat, usually green parts of a plant that are joined at one end to the stem or branch:

meanings.definition: a thin flat substance, esp. a sheet of paper, or a layer of something:
examples: Some of the leaves of the old book had come loose.

meanings.definition: A leaf of a table is an extra flat piece that can be added to the top surface to make the table larger.

meanings.word_type: noun[ C usually plural or U ]
meanings.definition: a vegetable with large, dark green leaves and thick white, red, or yellow stems:
examples: Leaf beets, including spinach beets and chards, are grown as leaf vegetables.
Leaf beet will grow happily in tubs.

meanings.definition: a piece of equipment for clearing leaves that have fallen from trees by blowing them away:
examples: Our gardener was clearing up with a leaf blower.
I use a leaf blower instead of a rake.

meanings.definition: a disease caused by a fungus (= a type of organism that gets its food from decaying material or other living things) that damages some fruit trees and causes them to produce less fruit:
examples: Peaches, nectarines, and almonds that have not been protected against leaf curl over winter can be sprayed with fungicide.
The variety is very resistant to peach leaf curl.

meanings.definition: a disease caused by a virus that affects some crops including cotton and tomatoes:
examples: The potted tomato plant I put out several weeks ago has started to develop leaf curl.
The decline in cotton production is attributed in part to a severe attack of leaf curl virus.

meanings.definition: a type of soft, white cooking fat without a strong taste, made from the fat near a pig's back and kidneys (= organs that remove waste). :
examples: Leaf lard has little to no pork flavour.

meanings.definition: a type of fertilizer (= substance that makes plants grow) made from leaves that fall from trees in the fall
a type of fertilizer (= substance that makes plants grow) made from leaves that fall from trees in the autumn
someone who visits a place to see the colours of the autumn leaves:
examples: It was fall and the leaf peepers were out in force.
They're known as leaf peepers – the thousands of tourists who cross the Atlantic to New England every autumn to watch the trees turn red and gold.

meanings.definition: a disease caused by a fungus (= a type of organism that gets its food from decaying material or other living things) that affects cereals (= plants grown to produce grain) and other crops:
examples: I have noticed quite a bit of leaf rust in the corn due to the cool and wet weather.
The fungus, called leaf rust, thrives in shady, moist environments.

meanings.definition: a disease that affects many crops and other plants and is caused by bacteria:
examples: Bacterial leaf scorch is a slow-killing disease with no known cure.

meanings.definition: damage to leaves caused by too much sun, too much or too little food, etc.:

meanings.definition: a plant disease caused by a fungus (= a type of organism that gets its food from decaying material and other living things), by bacteria, or by a virus that creates spots on the leaves:
examples: Despite the reports of leaf spot and other diseases, not all farmers are having a bad year.

meanings.definition: a group of people or countries that join together because they have the same interest:

meanings.definition: (of a liquid or gas) to escape from a hole or crack in a pipe or container; (of a container) to allow liquid or gas to escape:
examples: Water was leaking from the pipe.
Oil leaked out of the car.

The tin was leaking.

meanings.definition: to allow secret information to become generally known:
examples: He leaked the names to the press.

meanings.definition: To leak is also to give out information privately, esp. when people in authority do not want it to be known:

meanings.definition: A leak is also the act of giving out information privately, esp. when people in authority do not want it to be known:

meanings.word_type: verb[ I or T,  usually + adv/prep ]
meanings.definition: to (cause to) slope in one direction, or to move the top part of the body in a particular direction:
examples: She leaned forward and whispered something in my ear.
I sat down next to Bernard, who leaned over to me and said "You're late."

meanings.definition: Lean meat has little fat.
thin and healthy:
examples: lean and fit

meanings.definition: If a period of time is lean, there is not enough of something, especially money or food, at that time:
examples: It has been a particularly lean year for the education department.

meanings.definition: A lean company or organization does not use too many people or spend too much money, so that there is no waste:
examples: Nowadays even efficient, lean, well-run industries are failing.

meanings.definition: to move your body away from a vertical position so that it is bent forward or resting against something, or to place something in a sloping position against something:
examples: The conductor leaned over us and asked for our tickets.
She paused for a moment to rest and leaned against a large rock.
He leaned his bike against the wall.

meanings.definition: (of a person) thin and in good physical condition:
examples: Her body is lean, taut, athletic.

meanings.definition: When you describe meat as lean, you mean that it does not have much fat in it:
examples: lean hamburger meat

meanings.definition: A lean period is a time during which there is not enough of something, esp. money or food:
examples: It is a particularly lean year for science funding.

meanings.definition: When you say that a company or business is lean, you mean that it has the fewest employees it needs to do its work.
using fewer employees or less money in order to decrease waste, while continuing to operate effectively:
examples: Companies are downsizing, aiming to be leaner and more efficient, with demands on employees for greater productivity.
With the application of lean management principles, suppliers and distributors have streamlined their processes.
When it comes to costs, they pride themselves on running a lean operation.
The pack-houses and their workers have had to become leaner.
lean retailers/suppliers

meanings.definition: if a period of time is lean, there is not enough money or business at that time:
examples: lean period/times/years
Funding has been increased to some programs suffering from several years of lean budgets.

meanings.definition: if costs, goods for sale, materials, or quantities of workers are lean, they are very low, or kept as low as possible:
examples: Cold weather across the U.S. signaled a surge in demand for natural gas products at a time when inventories are uncomfortably lean.
Working quickly and cheaply, with lean staffs and even leaner budgets, contract manufacturers have long played a supporting role in the computer business.

meanings.definition: to sit or stand with part of your body touching something as a support:
examples: He leaned against the wall.

meanings.definition: to put something against a wall or other surface so that it is supported:
examples: She leaned the brush against the wall.

meanings.definition: showing a very strong and determined wish to get something:
examples: He's got that lean and hungry look.

meanings.definition: using only what is necessary, and determined to work effectively in order to compete successfully:
examples: Companies that have survived the crisis are going to be lean and mean.

meanings.definition: the business of producing goods in large numbers using methods that avoid waste and reduce the time taken:
examples: The factory has adopted a lean manufacturing programme to weed out waste in its production processes.
The use of multiskilled worker teams and flexible automated technology are key components of lean production.

meanings.definition: to use someone or something to help you, especially in a difficult situation:
examples: He's always had his big brother to lean on.

meanings.definition: to try to make someone do what you want by threatening or persuading them:
examples: We may have to lean on them a little if we want our money.

meanings.definition: to depend on someone or something:
examples: They had leaned on the dictionary as the authority that answered all their questions.

meanings.definition: to be interested in something and be likely to do a particular activity:

to make a large jump or sudden movement, usually from one place to another:
examples: He leaped out of his car and ran towards the house.

meanings.definition: to provide help, protection, etc. very quickly:

meanings.definition: to achieve something suddenly, usually fame, power, or importance:
examples: He leapt to fame after his appearance in a Broadway play.

meanings.definition: to increase, improve, or grow very quickly:

meanings.definition: a big change, increase, or improvement:

meanings.definition: a large jump or sudden movement:
examples: With one leap he crossed the stream.

meanings.definition: to make a large jump or sudden movement, or to jump over something:

fig. Americans want change, but they don’t want to leap into the unknown (= move quickly into unknown situations).

meanings.definition: If your heart leaps, you have a sudden, strong feeling of pleasure or fear:

meanings.definition: a large jump
to increase, improve, or grow very quickly:

meanings.definition: to eagerly accept the chance to do or have something:

meanings.definition: to accept an opportunity quickly and eagerly:

He is unable to concentrate on his work for any length of time (= for anything more than a short time).

meanings.definition: the amount of writing in a book or document:
examples: He's written books of various lengths on the subject.
All of your essays will be about the same length.

meanings.definition: long enough to reach the stated place:
examples: a knee-length skirt
shoulder-length hair

meanings.definition: of the stated amount of time:
examples: a full-length movie (= one which has not been shortened)

meanings.definition: the measurement of something from end to end or along its longest side, or a measurement of a particular part of something:
examples: a length of rope
The boat is 20 feet in length.

meanings.definition: The length of a piece of writing, such as a book or story, is a measure of the material it contains:
examples: The length of the poem was 30 lines.

meanings.definition: an amount of time:
examples: The movie is nearly three hours in length.
George went on about his illnesses at great/some length (= for a long time).

meanings.definition: to make something longer, or to become longer:
examples: I'll have to lengthen this skirt.
lengthening waiting lists

meanings.definition: If you lengthen something, or it lengthens, it takes longer to happen:
examples: There is a plan to lengthen the three-year course to four years.

meanings.definition: to make something longer, or to become longer:
examples: I’ll have to lengthen this skirt.
In the late afternoon, the shadows of the haystacks lengthened.

meanings.definition: to make something take longer to happen, or to become longer:
examples: There is a plan to lengthen the summer theater workshop to eight weeks.

to make something longer, or to become longer:

to make something longer, or to become longer:
