lengthening waiting lists

meanings.definition: If you lengthen something, or it lengthens, it takes longer to happen:
examples: There is a plan to lengthen the three-year course to four years.

meanings.definition: in a way that continues for a long time:
examples: They spoke seriously and lengthily to their own doctor as well as to a specialist.
The book is a lengthily researched field study of the culture of highest-level Washington.

meanings.definition: in the direction of the longest side:
examples: Cut the beans in half lengthways.

meanings.definition: in the direction of the longest side:
examples: Cut the pickles lengthwise.

meanings.definition: continuing for a long time:
examples: a lengthy discussion/process
Many airline passengers face lengthy delays because of the strike.

meanings.definition: taking a long time:
examples: a lengthy speech

meanings.definition: treatment in which someone is punished or judged less strongly or severely than would be expected:
examples: The defending lawyer asked for leniency on the grounds of her client's youth.
But for the leniency of the referee, the player would have been sent off.

meanings.definition: not as severe or strong in punishment or judgment as would be expected:
examples: They believe that judges are too lenient with terrorist suspects.
In view of the quantity of drugs involved, 16 years was the most lenient sentence (= punishment) the judge could impose.

meanings.definition: not as severe or strong in punishment or judgment as would be expected:
examples: Some felt that five years in prison was lenient, considering the suffering he had caused.

meanings.definition: in a way that punishes or judges someone less strongly or severely than would be expected:
examples: Because of her age, she was likely to be treated leniently in court.
He said senior officials caught in ethical lapses were treated more leniently than junior employees.

meanings.definition: the social, political, and economic principles and theories developed from Marxism by the Russian politician V. I. Lenin, supporting direct rule by workers
someone who believes in the social, political, and economic principles and theories developed from Marxism by the Russian politician V. I. Lenin, supporting direct rule by workers:
examples: Solzhenitsyn was strictly speaking a Leninist.
Radek reached an agreement with the Leninists.

meanings.definition: believing in the social, political, and economic principles and theories developed from Marxism by the Russian politician V. I. Lenin, supporting direct rule by workers:
examples: The world was ready to overlook the party's Leninist ideology.
Adopting tough Leninist language, he declared: "The oligarchs will cease to exist as a class."

meanings.definition: (of a speech sound) made without a lot of force
a curved piece of glass, plastic, or other transparent material, used in cameras, glasses, and scientific equipment, that makes objects seem closer, larger, smaller, etc.:
examples: a camera with a zoom lens

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         contact lens
the part of the eye behind the pupil (= the black hole at the front of the eye) that helps you to see clearly by focusing (= collecting) light onto the retina
a piece of glass or plastic having a curved surface in order to change the images that are received after going through it, usually to make them larger, smaller, or clearer:
examples: a camera lens
Her eyeglasses have thick lenses.

meanings.definition: a curved, transparent part of the eye that helps you to see clearly by directing images of light onto the retina (= the back surface of the eye)

past simple and past participle of
        
         lend
in the Christian religion, the 40 days before Easter, a period during which, for religious reasons, some people stop doing particular things that they enjoy:
examples: The children have promised to give up sweets for Lent.

meanings.definition: past simple and past participle of lend
in Christian religions, the 40 days before Easter
shaped like a round disc with surfaces that curve out slightly on both sides:
examples: The lenticular shape of this reef contrasts with the vertical-sided examples seen elsewhere in the region.
Lenticular clouds are quite strange in appearance and can be mistaken for flying saucers.

meanings.definition: relating to a lens (= a curved piece of glass or plastic that makes objects seem closer, or a part in your eye that does a similar thing):
examples: All three animals have lenticular sclerosis, which affects their eye lenses.

meanings.definition: used to describe a part of the body, especially in the brain, that is shaped like a round disc with surfaces that curve out slightly on both sides:
examples: These parts of the brain are collectively termed the lentiform nucleus.
This type of bleed outside the dura mater creates a lentiform bleed on the CT scan.

meanings.definition: one part of the four basal ganglia on each side of the brain that has an oval shape and helps process information, especially information that is related to movement and emotion:
examples: Differences in grey matter volume in the right lentiform nucleus, brain stem, and right thalamus were found.
MRI demonstrates injury to the lentiform nuclei.
Ventricular enlargement and increased lenticular nucleus volume were shown in the two patient groups.

meanings.definition: a very small dried bean that is cooked and eaten:
examples: lentil soup
red/green/brown lentils

meanings.definition: a small, round, flat seed, cooked and eaten in soups and other dishes
a large constellation (= a group of stars) said to look like a lion:
examples: Mercury lies close to the bright star Regulus in Leo.

meanings.definition: the fifth sign of the zodiac, relating to the period 23 July to 22 August, represented by a lion, or a person born during this period:
examples: They were both born under the sign of Leo.
My youngest son is a Leo.

meanings.definition: the fifth sign of the zodiac, covering the period July 23 to August 22 and represented by a lion, or a person born during this period
a type of large, strong-looking dog with thick, long hair that is brown, cream, or gold-coloured, with some black parts:
examples: He was absolutely devoted to his dog, a Leonberger.
She breeds pedigree Leonberger dogs at her home in England.

meanings.definition: (often of a person's head or hair) like a lion
a large wild cat that has yellow fur with black spots on it and lives in Africa and southern Asia
a large, wild cat that has yellow fur with black spots and that lives in Africa and south Asia
a tight piece of clothing that covers the body but not the legs, usually worn by female dancers or women doing physical exercise
a piece of clothing that fits tightly over the body from the shoulders to the tops of the legs, worn esp. by dancers and people exercising

abbreviation for 
        
         Large Electron Positron Collider  :
examples: Other results, from the LEP collider, indicate that the Higgs must weigh more than 114 billion electron volts.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Limited English Proficient: used to describe people, especially students, who do not have a good knowledge of English:
examples: They will continue to educate LEP students in their neighbourhood schools.
It is estimated that 12 percent of the county's student population is LEP.

meanings.definition: a person who is strongly disliked and avoided by other people because of something bad that he or she has done:
examples: She claimed that the rumours had made her a social leper.

meanings.definition: a word for a person who has leprosy (= a disease that damages a person's nerves and skin), which was used by doctors in the past but is now offensive
a person who has leprosy (= a disease of the nerves and skin)
someone who studies butterflies and moths (= flying insects with large wings):
examples: His father was a keen lepidopterist and had a large collection of butterflies and moths.

meanings.definition: the scientific study of butterflies and moths (= flying insects with large wings):
examples: His passion for lepidoptery led him to create a number of butterfly houses in Britain and abroad.
She was fascinated by lepidopterology and was often to be seen in a field with her butterfly net.

meanings.definition: (in old Irish stories) a magical creature in the shape of a little old man who likes to cause trouble
an infectious disease that damages a person's nerves and skin
an infectious disease that damages a person’s nerves and skin
a hormone (= a chemical made in the body) that controls feelings of hunger and the way the body stores fat:
examples: The identification of the hormone leptin transformed obesity research.
Leptin acts in the brain of rodents to reduce appetite.

meanings.definition: any very small piece of matter that is influenced by the weak force. electrons, muons, and neutrinos are all leptons.
any very small piece of matter that is influenced by the weak force. electrons, muons, and neutrinos are all leptons.
an infectious disease that damages the liver and kidneys, found mainly in dogs and farm animals and caused by bacteria
a woman who is sexually or romantically attracted to other women:
examples: gay men and lesbians

meanings.definition: belonging or relating to women who are sexually or romantically attracted to other women and not to people of other genders:
examples: They made history by becoming the first lesbian couple to be married in San Francisco.
The gay and lesbian community has sought employment protections.
The author's latest book is a lesbian love story set in the 1950s.

meanings.definition: a woman who is physically attracted to other women
the state of being a lesbian
an injury to a person's body or to an organ inside their body:
examples: skin/brain lesions

meanings.definition: an injury to a person’s body or to an organ
affected by or relating to a lesion (= an injury to a person's body or organ):
examples: We studied the lesional skin of patients suffering from scleroderma.
202 lesional samples were collected, including superficial spreading melanoma and nodular melanoma.

meanings.definition: a country in southern Africa
a smaller amount (of), or to a smaller degree:
examples: We must try to spend less money.
Exercise more and eat less.
I eat less chocolate and fewer biscuits than I used to.
Getting out of bed in summer is less difficult than in winter.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         minus  :
examples: The total is 30 dollars, less the five dollars deposit that you paid.

meanings.definition: used to form adjectives meaning "without (the thing mentioned)":
examples: meaningless
friendless

meanings.definition: a smaller amount of something, to a smaller degree, or not as much; comparative oflittle :
examples: We’ve got to spend less money.
It was less than a mile to the nearest gas station.
She had less reason to complain than I.
Skiing conditions this year are less than ideal (= not good).
There were no less than (= as many as) a thousand people buying tickets.

meanings.definition: minus ; after subtracting:
examples: $30, less the discount of 15%, is $25.50.

meanings.definition: after subtracting a particular number or amount:
examples: The account will pay at least base rate less 0.25% until 31 March next year.

meanings.definition: If something happens less and less, it becomes gradually smaller in amount or happens less often:
examples: He's less and less able to look after himself.
As their family grew, she had less and less time to write.
Americans do less and less of their shopping in malls these days.
Gradually, I started to depend less and less on other people to help me.
Employees started to travel less and less with each passing month.

meanings.definition: used for saying that a small amount or small changes are often more effective than a large amount or big changes:
examples: When it comes to makeup, less is more.
When the ingredients are top quality, less is more in terms of seasonings and sauces.

meanings.definition: having less importance or value than other people or things:
examples: You are assuming people who clean houses for money are somehow less-than.
We resent the fact that because of the colour of our skin, we are immediately categorized as less-than.

meanings.definition: having a smaller number or amount than
a country that does not have a lot of industrial activity and where people have low incomes:
examples: Governments in less developed countries realize that telecommunications access is one of the fastest engines of economic growth.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         LCL
a person who has the right to use something such as land, a building, or a piece of equipment, according to a lease (= legal agreement)
a person or organization that makes regular payments in order to use something that another person or organization owns:
examples: After three years, the lessees may sell their lease.

meanings.definition: If something lessens or is lessened, it becomes less strong:
examples: A healthy diet can lessen the risk of heart disease.

meanings.definition: to become or make something smaller in amount or degree:
examples: Keeping your weight down can lessen the risk of heart disease.

meanings.definition: to make something smaller, less noticeable, etc., or to become smaller, less noticeable, etc.:
examples: Corporate executives are keen to embrace "green technology" in order to lessen their dependence on fossil fuels.
Increasing security procedures is the only way to lessen the risks of air travel.
Experts argue that a carbon tax would lessen the influence of special-interest groups in the climate change debate.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         lessen
If something lessens or is lessened, it becomes less strong:
examples: A healthy diet can lessen the risk of heart disease.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         lessen
If something lessens or is lessened, it becomes less strong:
examples: A healthy diet can lessen the risk of heart disease.

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is not as great in size, amount, or importance as something else:
examples: A lesser man (= a man who was not as strong or brave) might have given up at that point.
The charge of murder was altered to the lesser (= less serious) charge of manslaughter.
Ethiopia and, to a lesser extent/degree, Kenya will be badly affected by the drought.

meanings.definition: not as great in size, amount, or importance as something else:
examples: Texas and, to a lesser degree, Oklahoma will be affected by the drought.

meanings.definition: a small plant in the buttercup family that has shiny yellow flowers and is poisonous to horses, sheep, and cows:
examples: Traditional spring plants such as the lesser celandine can now be seen in January rather than March.
Lesser celandines are now at their best in damp spots beside the lanes.

meanings.definition: not as popular or famous as something else:
examples: We stayed on one of the lesser-known Greek islands.

meanings.definition: a period of time in which a person is taught about a subject or how to do something:
examples: How can we make science lessons more interesting?
She has never had/taken any acting lessons.
He gives French lessons.

meanings.definition: an experience that teaches you how to behave better in a similar situation in the future:
examples: There is a lesson for all parents in this tragic accident.
My parents made me pay back all the money and it was a lesson I never forgot.
We can learn important lessons (= gain new understanding) from this disaster.

meanings.definition: a period of time during which something is taught:
examples: Have you ever taken piano lessons?

meanings.definition: A lesson is also a useful piece of information learned through experience:
examples: Losing his job was a lesson he never forgot.

meanings.definition: a person who allows someone to use something that they own, such as land, a building, or a piece of equipment, according to a lease (= legal agreement)
a person or organization that allows another person or organization to use something they own in return for regular payments:
examples: An asset may be repossessed by the lessor in the event of a default on the lease payments.

meanings.definition: in order to prevent any possibility that something will happen:
examples: They were afraid to complain about the noise lest they annoyed the neighbours.

meanings.definition: for fear that:
examples: Gramps is too frightened to move, lest he disturb the infant.

meanings.definition: to allow something to happen or someone to do something by not doing anything to stop an action or by giving your permission:
examples: She wanted to go but her parents wouldn't let her.
He decided to let his hair grow long.
Let your shoes dry completely before putting them on.
I'm letting you stay up late, just this once.
Don't let it worry you.
If he needs money, let him (= he should) earn it!

meanings.definition: used to show that you accept what is going to happen, although you do not like it:
examples: Let it rain - it won't spoil our afternoon.

meanings.definition: used to say that you wish something to happen very much:
examples: Oh, please let him get the job!

meanings.definition: to allow your house or land to be lived in or used by someone else in exchange for a regular payment:
examples: They are letting their house (out) for the summer.
He's let his flat to a young couple.
She has a room to let in her house.

meanings.definition: (in tennis or similar games) a situation in which the ball touches the net as it crosses it, so that you have to play the point again
the act of allowing someone to use your house, land, etc. in exchange for regular payments:
examples: a five-year let on a flat

meanings.definition: small, not very important:
examples: piglet

meanings.definition: to allow something to happen or someone to do something by giving permission or by not doing anything to stop it from happening:
examples: Fraya’s parents let her go to the movie.
He decided to let his hair grow long.
She opened the door and let me in (= allowed me to enter).
After questioning him for six hours, the police finally let him go (= released him).

meanings.definition: to cause something to happen or to be in a particular condition, or to cause someone to understand something:
examples: He let the pool empty.
Let me know if you need help.
He let out a shout (= He shouted).

meanings.definition: to allow something to happen, or to allow someone to do something, by giving your permission or by not doing anything to stop an action:
examples: We do not let our staff use social networking sites at work.
They had let the office accommodation become rundown and shabby.

meanings.definition: to allow your house or land to be lived in or used by someone else in exchange for a regular payment:
examples: They are letting their house out for the summer.
He's let his flat to a young couple.
The Technology Park has office accommodation and business units to let.
The property is let on a 10-year lease.
The holiday apartments are let on a weekly basis.

meanings.definition: the act of allowing someone to use your house, land, etc. in exchange for regular payments:
examples: a five-year let on a flat
We've taken the studios on a short-term let.

meanings.definition: used after a negative statement to emphasize how unlikely a situation is because something much more likely has never happened:
examples: Some people never even read a newspaper, let alone a book.
He could hardly touch his knees, let alone his toes.
There wasn't enough to keep us occupied for an afternoon, let alone the whole weekend.
I barely had time to take a shower, let alone make home-cooked meals.
I wouldn't want to be in the same room as that woman, let alone date her.

meanings.definition: used to tell someone that they should forget about unpleasant things that happened in the past, and especially to forgive and forget something bad that someone has done to them:
examples: Just let bygones be bygones and be friends again.
Why can't you let bygones be bygones and put it all behind you?
My mother thinks I should let bygones be bygones but I'm struggling with it.
After all these years, surely it's time to let bygones be bygones.
If she's willing, I'm willing to let bygones be bygones.

meanings.definition: to stop holding something or someone:
examples: Brandon let go of her hand and ran across the street.

meanings.definition: to stop holding something: to stop thinking about or being angry about the past or something that happened in the past:
examples: Hold on tight and don't let go!
Let go of my hand, you're hurting me!
She finds it hard to let go of a grudge.
You need to let the past go and forgive those who have hurt you.

meanings.definition: to allow someone to be free: to make someone leave their job:
examples: He pleaded with them to let him go.
The firm hired the staff to sell the stocks, then let most of them go only a few months after the crash.

meanings.definition: to allow yourself to become less attractive or healthy: to relax completely and enjoy yourself:
examples: It's easy to let yourself go when you've got small kids.
It's a party - let yourself go!

meanings.definition: to stop taking care of something such as a house or garden:
examples: The house was beautiful, but the new owners have just let it go.

meanings.definition: to be more relaxed than usual and enjoy yourself:
examples: Just let go and have a little fun!
I like to let my hair down on the dance floor.

meanings.definition: to end someone’s employment:
examples: We had to let fourteen employees go last month.

meanings.definition: to take less care of your appearance:
examples: He's gained a lot of weight lately, and kind of let himself go.

meanings.definition: to behave freely without being shy or feeling worried about what other people will think of you
to make certain that people know something:
examples: I let it be known that I was not happy about the decision that had been made.

meanings.definition: to take no action about something:
examples: Instead of going to the police they let things lie for a couple of months.

meanings.definition: used when you want to think for a moment about something:
examples: "Is there a shop that sells sports clothes?" "Let me see - I think there's one near here."

meanings.definition: to allow someone or something to live or die naturally:
examples: He could be kept alive artificially, but I think it would be kinder to let nature take its course.

meanings.definition: to allow something to happen naturally:
examples: Usually the Park Service lets nature take its course and does not replace dead trees.

meanings.definition: to do or say something that helps you to get rid of strong feelings or energy:
examples: She jogs after work to let off steam.

meanings.definition: to tell other people about something that you know, especially when it is a secret:
examples: I suspect he knows more than he's letting on.

meanings.definition: to tell other people about something that you know, esp. when it is a secret:
examples: If he did know the truth, he didn’t let on.

meanings.definition: to behave in an angry and emotional way:
examples: She let rip about the state of the kitchen.

meanings.definition: said to warn someone that they should not talk about a bad situation that most people have forgotten about
to stop criticizing or annoying someone:
examples: Just let her alone – she’s not bothering you.

meanings.definition: to disappoint someone by failing to do what you agreed to do or were expected to do:
examples: You will be there tomorrow - you won't let me down, will you?
When I was sent to prison, I really felt I had let my parents down.

meanings.definition: If you let down a piece of clothing, you make it longer:
examples: My trousers shrank in the wash so I let them down.

meanings.definition: If you let down something filled with air, you cause the air to go out of it:
examples: Someone let my tyres down while I was at the gym.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to be disappointed, often because you have failed to do what you promised:
examples: You’ll be there tomorrow – you won’t let me down, will you?

meanings.definition: to attack, criticize, or punish someone very forcefully:
examples: He arrived late to meet his girlfriend at the airport. She gave him both barrels.
England football fans can expect to be hit with both barrels if they misbehave during next month's European Championship finals.

meanings.definition: to attack someone with words or physically
to attack someone, either with words or physically:
examples: When Joe finally got home three hours late, Lea let him have it.

let-in-on-a-secret.name: let someone in on a secret

meanings.definition: to allow someone to know something that you have not told anyone else:
examples: Can I let you in on a little secret?

meanings.definition: to tell someone about something that is secret, or to allow someone to become involved in something that only very few people are involved in:
examples: Debbie agreed to let me in on her plans.

meanings.definition: to tell someone something, esp. private information, that others already know:
examples: My children never want to let me in on what they do in school.

meanings.definition: to tell someone something:
examples: Let us know when you get there.
Let me know if you need any help.
Thank you for coming to the interview - we'll let you know (= tell you whether we are going to offer you a job) in the next week.

meanings.definition: to allow someone to do what they want in a place:
examples: You don't want to let Oliver loose in the kitchen.

meanings.definition: If you let loose something such as bullets or bombs, you release a lot of them all together: to suddenly make a sound or speak in an uncontrolled way:
examples: The allies let loose an intensive artillery bombardment over the border.
He turned around and let loose a torrent of abuse.

meanings.definition: to not punish someone who has committed a crime or done something wrong, or to not punish them severely:
examples: Instead of a prison sentence they were let off with a fine.
You won't be let off so lightly (= you will be punished more severely) the next time.

meanings.definition: to fire a gun, or to make something such as a bomb or fireworks explode:
examples: Don't let off fireworks near the house.

meanings.definition: to fail to punish someone when the person expects to be punished, or to fail to punish someone severely enough:
examples: The boys were let off with a reprimand.

meanings.definition: to allow someone to escape from a difficult situation:
examples: John's agreed to go to the meeting in my place so that lets me off the hook.
He denied leaking the documents to get himself off the hook.

meanings.definition: to allow someone or something to enter:
examples: She opened the door and let me in.
These shoes are starting to let water in.

meanings.definition: to allow someone or something to leave a place, especially by opening a closed or locked door:
examples: I heard a voice from the cupboard shouting "Let me out!"

meanings.definition: to cause something to come out:
examples: He let the air out of the balloon.
She let out a scream (= she made this noise).

meanings.definition: to make a piece of clothing wider by removing the sewing from the sides and sewing closer to the edge of the material:
examples: These trousers are too tight - I'm going to have to let them out.

meanings.definition: When something that people go to, such as school or a show, lets out, it ends and everyone leaves:
examples: When does school let out for the summer?

meanings.definition: (of a class or school) to end or be finished:
examples: My history class lets out at 4:15.
When does your school let out for the summer?

meanings.definition: to make a piece of clothing wider or larger by changing where it is sewn or adding more cloth:
examples: Can this skirt be let out?

meanings.definition: to make certain that people are aware of a fact:
examples: She let it be known that she did not want to run again for Congress.

meanings.definition: to not correct or argue with something that a person says or does that is wrong:
examples: I know what he said wasn't strictly accurate but I let it pass anyway.

meanings.definition: to put something into a flat surface so that it does not stick out:
examples: A skylight had been let into the roof.

meanings.definition: to not talk about or mention a particular subject:
examples: After he had told his friends he was writing a novel, they wouldn't let the subject rest.

meanings.definition: to not take any action to stop something wrong or unpleasant, thinking that action may not be necessary or is not yet necessary:
examples: Don't panic about the low sales - let it ride for a while and see if business picks up.

meanings.definition: to tell people about something without intending to:
examples: He let it slip that he hadn't actually read the report.

meanings.definition: to not do anything about something or someone when you should try to change or correct that thing or person:
examples: I knew he wasn’t telling me everything, but I decided to let it slide.
It’s easy to let exercise slide in the suburbs where you have to drive your car all the time.

let-the-cat-out-of-the-bag.name: let the cat out of the bag

meanings.definition: to allow a secret to be known, usually without intending to:
examples: I was trying to keep the party a secret, but Mel went and let the cat out of the bag.

let-the-genie-out-of-the-bottle.name: let the genie out of the bottle

meanings.definition: to allow something to happen that cannot then be stopped:
examples: When I told her the secret, I let the genie out of the bottle.

meanings.definition: to behave in a way that embarrasses or disappoints a group of people that you are part of
If bad weather or an unpleasant situation lets up, it stops or improves:
examples: When the rain lets up we'll go for a walk.

meanings.definition: to stop doing something that you have been doing continuously or in a determined way:
examples: Neil spent the entire evening moaning about his job - he just wouldn't let up.
The police insist that they are not letting up on their campaign against drugs.

meanings.definition: a pause or reduction in something, usually something bad:
examples: The airline authorities are not expecting a let-up in delays (= are not expecting delays to stop) for the rest of the summer.

meanings.definition: (esp. of something unpleasant) to become less strong or stop:
examples: When the rain lets up we’ll go for a walk.

meanings.definition: to stop treating someone severely, or to stop doing something so forcefully:
examples: He advised her to let up on the relentless criticism.

meanings.definition: to allow yourself to behave much more freely than usual and enjoy yourself:
examples: Oh let your hair down for once!

meanings.definition: to become involved in a difficult or unpleasant situation without intending to:
examples: Do you realize how much extra work you're letting yourself in for?

meanings.definition: something that you say before you say something that is unpleasant but true:
examples: Let's face it, we both know why I stopped working there.
Let's face it, we're not going to win.

meanings.definition: said before stating something that is unpleasant but true:
examples: Let's face it, we're not going to win.

meanings.definition: we should accept the truth:
examples: Let’s face it, I’m never going to be a great artist.

meanings.definition: used to encourage someone to try hard and be successful:
examples: Wake up everyone - let's get this bread!
Happy Monday - let's get the bread.

meanings.definition: used when you want to think carefully about something or are trying to remember:
examples: Next Saturday, let's see, that's when we're going to the theatre.
The last time I spoke to her was, now let me think, three weeks ago.

meanings.definition: I am thinking about this: Let’s see is also used when you want to discover something:
examples: "How many people will be there?" "Well, let’s see – I think it's about 20."
Now that we know what your interests are, let’s see if we can match you to a job you’d like.

meanings.definition: used to introduce a suggestion or possible example of something:
examples: Try and finish the work by, let's say, Friday.
Say/Let's say (= if we accept) (that) the journey takes three hours, then you'd be there by two o'clock.

meanings.definition: to do or say something that helps you to get rid of strong feelings or energy:
examples: He lifts weights after work to let off steam.

meanings.definition: to allow an animal to run around freely after it has been tied up:
examples: She let her horse loose in the field.

meanings.definition:
informal for
        
         lecher disapproving
a disappointment:
examples: After all I'd heard about the movie, it turned out to be a bit of a letdown.

meanings.definition: an act of disappointing someone; disappointment:
examples: It was quite a letdown when Joyce only got a grade of C on the final exam.

meanings.definition: able to cause or causing death; extremely dangerous:
examples: Three minutes after the fire started, the house was full of lethal fumes.
In the car the police found guns, knives, and other lethal weapons (= weapons that can kill).
A 59-year-old man was executed by lethal injection (= by having a poisonous substance put into his body) this morning.
That combination of tiredness and alcohol is lethal (= has a very bad effect).

meanings.definition: able to cause or causing death; extremely dangerous:
examples: a lethal weapon

meanings.definition: an amount of something, especially a drug, that is large enough to cause death:
examples: Twenty or thirty of these pills would be a lethal dose.
She received a lethal dose of radiation.

meanings.definition: an injection of a drug that kills someone, especially as a punishment for committing a crime:
examples: He was executed by lethal injection in 2010.

meanings.definition: in a way that can cause death or is extremely dangerous:
examples: Some of these drugs are lethally dangerous.
The virus has killed or lethally infected 30 million people.

meanings.definition: having little energy; feeling unwilling and unable to do anything:
examples: I was feeling tired and lethargic.

meanings.definition: lacking in energy; feeling unwilling or unable to do anything
with little energy or in a way that shows you are unwilling to do something:
examples: Jane rose lethargically from her bed.
He played lethargically and stood and watched his teammates.

meanings.definition: the feeling of having little energy or of being unable or unwilling to do anything:
examples: Symptoms include loss of appetite, lethargy, and vomiting.

meanings.definition: a written message from one person to another, usually put in an envelope and sent by post:
examples: I got a letter from the bank this morning.

meanings.definition: any of the set of symbols used to write a language, representing a sound in the language:
examples: the letter D

meanings.definition: a prize in the shape of the first letter of the name of a high school or university, given to a student for achievement in sport and sometimes other activities, and often worn on a special jacket or sweater:
examples: A naturally gifted athlete, he earned four letters in basketball and two more in baseball at high school.
Her mission was to win a letter in basketball by the time she was a senior in high school.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a standard size of paper in the US, 8.5 inches by 11 inches:
examples: Fliers are usually printed either on letter size or legal size paper.

meanings.definition: If a student letters in a particular sport, they are given a prize for achievement in sport in the shape of the first letter of the name of their high school or university, which is often worn on a special jacket or sweater:
examples: She lettered in five varsity sports in high school.
Twelve juniors lettered for the Tigers last season.

meanings.definition: a written or printed message from one person to another, usually put in an envelope and delivered as mail:
examples: I got a letter from the bank this morning.

meanings.definition: any of the set of symbols used to write a language, in many languages, representing a sound in the language:
examples: She wrote her name on the board in large letters.

meanings.definition: a written message from one person to another, usually put in an envelope and sent by mail:
examples: You will receive an acknowledgement by letter.
I got a letter from my lawyer this morning.
I sent a letter about the problem to HQ last week.
The letter was signed by the managing director.
I wrote to the company but they did not even acknowledge my letter.
You will receive a confirmation letter within 10 working days.
Please find enclosed my CV and a covering letter.
He wrote a formal letter of resignation.
The letter was addressed to John Clarke.
a letter dated 3rd March 2010

meanings.definition: any of the set of symbols used to write a language, representing a sound in the language:
examples: the letter D
an upper-case/lower-case letter (= A/a or B/b)

an official letter asking for a reduction in the amount of something, or that something should stop:

meanings.definition: a formal letter to tell someone that you have done some something or that something has happened:
examples: She wrote a standard letter of advice to notify her client of the proposed changes.

meanings.definition: a letter showing the details of a formal agreement between two or more people or companies:
examples: The letter of agreement was signed by both parties.

meanings.definition: a letter telling someone how many shares they are being offered when new shares are being made available to buy
a letter telling someone how many shares they have been given when new shares are being made available to buy
a letter giving reasons why someone should consider a decision again because you think the original decision was wrong:
examples: He helped me write a letter of appeal against my dismissal.

a legal document that gives someone the authority to act for someone else in business or financial matters
a letter from a company that tells a bank that it supports a request for a loan made by one of its subsidiary companies (= one of the companies that it owns):
examples: The parent company withdrew its letter of comfort and the funding required to sustain the subsidiary.

meanings.definition: a letter from an accountant about a company that is selling shares for the first time, that states that the information in the company's accounts is correct:
examples: The function of the letter of comfort is to reduce the underwriters' liability risk resulting from a misleading prospectus.

meanings.definition: a letter from a bank allowing the person who has it to take a particular amount of money from a bank in another country

a financial document in which a bank formally promises to pay a particular amount of money into the bank of a person selling goods if the goods are delivered by an agreed date and in an acceptable condition. Buyers often use letters of credit to buy goods from other countries:
examples: The bank issued the letter of credit on the instructions of the importer.
For export sales, the price of the goods are secured by a letter of credit.

meanings.definition: in a situation in which bonds, etc. are sold, a written promise by a bank to pay the lender if the borrower is unable to do so:
examples: The notes are secured by bank letters of credit.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         credit dispute letter
a formal document describing the conditions under which someone is employed to do work for a company:
examples: The fees will be as set out in the letter of engagement.

meanings.definition: a letter to a bank or other company that has lent you money to buy a house, etc. explaining why you are unable to make a payment or asking to pay less than usual

a legal document in which a person or company promises to pay for any loss that happens as a result of them doing a particular task. Letters of indemnity are often used when transporting goods by ship:
examples: The letter of indemnity protects the shipping company against any claims that may arise from the issue of a clean Bill of Lading.

meanings.definition: a formal letter to ask for new share certificates (= documents) to replace the original certificates that you have lost:
examples: Where a certificate is lost, stolen or missing, completion of a letter of indemnity is required.

meanings.definition: a letter that formally states what someone plans to do although this is not a legal promise or official contract:
examples: The company has signed a letter of intent but the full agreement has not been finalized.

meanings.definition: a written document by someone who is owed money in which they formally agree to allow more time for the debt to be paid back
a letter describing someone's qualities and abilities, written by someone who worked with them previously, and sent to a possible new employer:
examples: To apply, send a CV and two letters of recommendation to the four people listed below: ...

meanings.definition: a letter that tells someone a piece of bad news such as the fact that they have failed to get a job, etc.:
examples: We sent out a letter of regret to unsuccessful candidates.

meanings.definition: a knife for opening envelopes that is not sharp and is often decorative
used to describe words produced without any mistakes, or a person who is able to repeat a particular text from memory without making any mistakes:
examples: His mother rehearsed his lines with him and by the time the play opened he was letter-perfect.
"Your German was letter-perfect," Franz said.
a letter-perfect rendition/recitation

meanings.definition: used to describe paper that measures 8½ inches by 11 inches (= 21.59 cm by 27.94 cm), the standard size of office paper in the US:
examples: I reformatted my document to print it on letter-size paper.
The calendars will be printed on US letter paper.

meanings.definition: a rectangular hole in the door or in a wall near the entrance of a house or other building, through which letters, etc. are delivered
a metal container in the street or other public place in which you can put letters for them to be collected and sent to someone else
an artist who creates the text for a comic or graphic novel (= a book whose story is told in pictures):
examples: He was a letterer on black and white comic strips.
Letterers do the script in the balloons.

meanings.definition: the top part of a piece of writing paper where the name and address of a person or business is printed
the printing at the top of a piece of writing paper telling the name and address of the person or business sending the letter
Letterhead is also the paper that this information is printed on.
the name and address of a person or company that is printed at the top of a piece of writing paper:
examples: The letters were printed on paper with the official company letterhead.

meanings.definition: paper that has the name and address of a person or company printed at the top:
examples: The form must be printed on letterhead.

meanings.definition: writing in a particular colour, style, etc.:
examples: a black box with gold lettering

meanings.definition: written letters:
examples: The perfume comes in a black box with gold lettering.

meanings.definition: writing in a particular colour, style, etc.:
examples: The company name appeared on the sign in gold lettering.

meanings.definition: someone who has been given a letter (= a prize in the shape of the first letter of the name of a high school, college, or university, given to a student for achievement in sport, and often worn on their jacket):
examples: He was a sports letterman in high school.

meanings.definition: a jacket, often with sleeves that are a different colour from the rest of the jacket, that fits tightly round the waist and fastens with a zip
a method of printing in which raised surfaces covered with ink are pressed onto paper

(in the UK) a document written by a court that gives someone the right to manage a dead person's money and property, especially after the person has died without leaving a will (= a legal document describing who should receive someone's property after they die):
examples: an application to the High Court for the grant of letters of administration

meanings.definition: a formal document from a king, queen, or government that gives someone a particular right:
examples: The coat of arms was granted by letters patent of Edward IV.

meanings.definition: a company that is paid by other companies to send letters and advertisements to large numbers of people:
examples: Our lettershop handles high-volume direct mailings.
We offer a full lettershop service.

meanings.definition: a room or building that can be rented:
examples: The town offers several holiday lettings.

meanings.definition: the activity of allowing your house or land to be lived in or used by someone else in exchange for a regular payment:
examples: The government wants to encourage the letting of empty properties.
Landlords can use a letting agent to find tenants.
She's been renting a house through a letting agency.
We can offer short-term lettings in most locations.

meanings.definition: a room or building that can be rented:
examples: They own a number of holiday lettings in France.

meanings.definition: a plant with large, green leaves, eaten uncooked in salads
a plant of large, green leaves, eaten raw in salads
the stopping or slowing down of something that is unpleasant:
examples: Since the mall was built, there’s been no letup in traffic.

a serious disease in which the body produces too many white blood cells
a serious disease in which the body produces too many white blood cells
a disease in which the body produces too many white blood cells, causing weakness and sometimes death

a 
        
         white blood cell
belonging to or relating to the Levant or its people
a person from the Levant
a muscle that raises part of the body
a wall made of soil or other materials that is built next to a river to stop the river from overflowing (= coming out of a place because it is too full)
a wall made of land or other materials that is built to stop a river from overflowing (= flowing over its edges):
examples: Much of the city was under water after floods broke levees and forced the evacuation of 50,000 people.

meanings.definition: the height of something:
examples: The water level in the lake is much higher after heavy rain.

meanings.definition: the amount or number of something:
examples: Inflation is going to rise two percent from its present level.
Chess requires a very high level of concentration.
There is some danger of low level (= a continuing small amount of) radiation.

meanings.definition: someone's ability compared to other people:
examples: a class for advanced level students
Students at this level require a lot of help.
The exam can be taken at three levels.

meanings.definition: a floor in a large building:
examples: The library has three levels, with a conference centre at ground level.
The exhibition is on level three of the building.

meanings.definition: a position within a system in which people are arranged according to their importance:
examples: These are subjects for discussion at management level.

meanings.definition: a tool that contains a tube of liquid with an air bubble in it, used to show if a surface is level
at the same height:
examples: The top of the tree is level with his bedroom window.

meanings.definition: flat or horizontal:
examples: Make sure the camera is level before you take the picture.
Before I bang the nails in, would you say this picture was level?

meanings.definition: having the same value, amount, number of points, etc.:
examples: Pieretti would have to win the next three stages in order to draw level with (= reach the same position as) Le Sage in the Tour de France.
The unions are fighting to keep wages level (US usually even) with inflation.

meanings.definition: If you speak in a level voice or give someone a level look, you do it in a calm and controlled way:
examples: In a level voice, he ordered the soldiers to aim and fire.

meanings.definition: to make a surface flat:
examples: Level the wet cement before it sets.

meanings.definition: to completely destroy a building or area:
examples: The bombing levelled the village.

meanings.definition: (of a surface) not rising or falling or higher on one side, but even in all directions; horizontal or flat:
examples: The table wobbles because the floor is not level.

meanings.definition: Something that is level with something else is at the same height:
examples: The top of the tree is level with his bedroom window.

meanings.definition: A level spoon or cup is filled with something just to the top edge.
If you speak in a level voice, you speak in a calm and controlled way.
a particular position, degree, or amount of something, esp. compared with other possible positions, degrees, or amounts:
examples: The water level in the lake is higher after a heavy rain.
The big debate is whether more decisions should be made at the local level or at the national level.
He achieved a high level of skill as an interpreter.
We publish a dictionary for intermediate level students.

meanings.definition: A level is also one of several floors at different heights in a building:
examples: The reception area is on the ground level.

meanings.definition: a tool containing a tube of liquid with an air bubble in it, which shows whether a surface is horizontal by the position of the bubble
to aim or direct something at someone or something:
examples: Soldiers leveled their weapons.
Criticism of the program was leveled by a number of politicians.

meanings.definition: to make something level:
examples: We had to level the backyard before putting up the pool.

meanings.definition: To level buildings or other structures is to destroy them by causing them to fall down:
examples: Her grandfather survived the 1906 earthquake that leveled San Francisco.

meanings.definition: the amount of something that exists, especially when it is counted or measured:
examples: Unions are calling for pay increases above the current level of inflation.
We must reduce the risks to an acceptable level.
The city has high levels of unemployment.
The FTSE 100 index rose to its highest level since July 2009.
This policy reduces the level of demand in the economy.
There are increased levels of consumer debt.
Staff currently receive the minimum level of pay allowable by law.

meanings.definition: a degree or standard of something:
examples: We provide a high level of customer support.
Users expect a basic level of service.
We hope to achieve improved levels of performance.

meanings.definition: a position or rank within an organization or a system:
examples: Candidates must have significant experience at a senior level.
Training is available to staff at all levels within the organization.
Managers at every level are tasked with cutting costs.
These decisions are made at board level.

meanings.definition: one of the floors in a building:
examples: The rest rooms are situated at ground level.

meanings.definition: having the same value, amount, etc. as before, or as something else:
examples: Interest rates are expected to remain level for the next six months.
Overall, sales were level with those for the same period last year.

meanings.definition: to become worse or less, or to make something worse or less, so that it is the same as something else:
examples: Many schools are being levelled down, rather than improved.

meanings.definition: a place where a railway and a road cross each other, usually with gates that stop the traffic while a train goes past
If a rate or amount levels off, it stops rising or falling and stays at the same level:
examples: House prices now seem to be levelling off after the steep rises of the last few years.
Unemployment rose to ten percent and then levelled off.

meanings.definition: to stop increasing or being reduced:
examples: The price of gas has finally leveled off after rising for several months.
The plane descended to 18,000 feet before leveling off.

meanings.definition: if a rate or amount levels off, it stops rising or falling and stays at the same level:
examples: Share prices are beginning to level off after the sharp rises of recent months.
The bank expects that growth will level off at 2.5% next spring.
We assume rates will level out at 5.25%.

meanings.definition: If an aircraft levels off/out, it starts to travel horizontally rather than going up or down:
examples: The jet levelled off at 10, 000 feet.

meanings.definition: in an equal position in a competition or game:
examples: Both teams are level pegging.

meanings.definition: to accuse someone in public of doing something wrong:
examples: Criticism has been levelled at senior figures in the industry.
Charges of corruption have been levelled against him.

meanings.definition: to aim something such as a weapon at someone:
examples: She picked up the gun and levelled it at me.

meanings.definition: an amount of a liquid or substance that fills a spoon/cup but does not go above the edges, used as a measure in cooking:
examples: Add two level spoonfuls of cocoa powder to the mixture.
Put a level tablespoonful of butter into the pan.
Use one level teaspoonful of salt for every pint of water.
You will need two level cupfuls of flour.
Stir in one level cupful of brown sugar.

meanings.definition: to accuse someone in public of doing something wrong:
examples: Criticism has been levelled at senior figures in the industry.

meanings.definition: to gain enough points in a computer game to enable a player or character to go up to a higher level, gaining more skills or strength
to go to a higher level, or to reach the same high level as something else:
examples: Why not level up to our premium version?

Brick-and-mortar retailers have traditionally lagged behind online retailers in using consumer information to create personalized shopping experiences, but progressive retailers are quickly levelling up.

meanings.definition: to increase pay, living standards, the number of jobs, etc. in areas of the country where they are lower than in others, so that all areas are more equal:
examples: It is essential that no region is left behind as the country levels up.

meanings.definition: to improve standards in one place, area of activity etc. so that they are the same as another place, area of activity etc. where standards were higher:
examples: This approach has levelled standards up across the sector.

meanings.definition: to increase pay, living standards, the number of jobs, etc. in areas of the country where they are lower than in others, so that all areas are more equal:
examples: The UK government's most important mission is to unite and level up the country.

meanings.definition: (in computer games) to get more skills, etc. for a character in a game by winning points:
examples: Here are all the tips and tricks you need to know on how to level up your characters quickly.

meanings.definition: to improve or increase, or to make something improve or increase, so that it is as good as something else:
examples: Pension benefits for women have been levelled up to match those of men.

meanings.definition: to tell someone the truth about something:
examples: I'll level with you - the salary's not particularly good, and there's little chance of promotion.

meanings.definition: to tell someone the truth, esp. when it may be unpleasant:
examples: I’ll level with you – the salary is not particularly good.

meanings.definition: calm and able to deal easily with difficult situations
able to be calm in difficult situations
something, typically death, that affects people of every class and rank in the same way, making everyone seem equal:
examples: death, the great leveler

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         levelling up

past simple and past participle of 
        
         level
something, typically death, that affects people of every class and rank in the same way, making everyone seem equal:
examples: death, the great leveller

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         level
the practice of improving standards in one place, area of activity etc. so that they are the same as another place, area of activity etc. where standards were higher:
examples: It leads to a levelling down of standards rather than a levelling up.
He stressed that the lawsuit seeks a levelling up of state aid, and not state aid reductions to wealthy suburban districts.

meanings.definition: the practice of increasing pay, jobs, living standards, etc. in areas of the country where they are lower than in other areas, so that all areas are more equal:
examples: Many called for more social and regional levelling up.
The government has a very obvious vested interest in levelling up - it needs to keep former Labour voters onside.

meanings.definition: in a calm way without showing any emotion:
examples: He looked levelly across at me.

meanings.definition: a bar or handle that moves around a fixed point, so that one end of it can be pushed or pulled in order to control the operation of a machine or move a heavy or stiff object
something you use, often unfairly, to try to persuade someone to do what you want
to move a bar or handle around a fixed point, so that one end of it can be pushed or pulled in order to control the operation of a machine or move a heavy or stiff object:
examples: She levered up the drain cover.
He levered open the engine compartment and released a great cloud of blue smoke.

meanings.definition: If you lever someone or something to a place, you move them there with great physical effort:
examples: He levered himself out of his chair with the usual difficulty and opened his arms wide.
Jim fought to pull himself up, levering his arms down.

meanings.definition: to change a situation in order to suit yourself, often using unfair methods:
examples: The company gobbles up rivals or levers them out of the market.
They accused the companies of using political pressure to lever out competition.

meanings.definition: a handle that you move to control the operation of a machine:
examples: He pushed the lever into the "on" position and started the machine.

meanings.definition: A lever is also a bar, moving over a fixed point, that when pressed down at one end can move or lift something at the other end.
a bar or handle which moves around a fixed point, so that one end of it can be pushed or pulled in order to control a machine or move a heavy object:
examples: Lower the lever to lock the machine into place.

meanings.definition: something you use to try to persuade someone to do what you want or to get the result you want:
examples: Using trade or other economic tools as a lever of diplomacy is not new.
If your mortgage offer is less than you wanted, it may be a useful lever for getting the price of the house down.

meanings.definition: to try to persuade someone to do what you want, or try to get a particular result:
examples: But the government has not allowed the market to lever employers into that position.

meanings.definition: a type of large container used to hold paper, in which paper is held on two large, curved pieces of metal that are opened or closed using a metal bar
a type of large container used to hold paper, in which paper is held on two big curved pieces of metal documents that are opened or closed using a metal bar
the action or advantage of using a lever:
examples: Using ropes and wooden poles for leverage, they haul sacks of cement up the track.

meanings.definition: power to influence people and get the results you want:
examples: If the United Nations had more troops in the area, it would have greater leverage.

meanings.definition: the relationship between the amount of money that a company owes to banks and the value of the company
the act of using borrowed money to buy an investment or a company:
examples: With leverage, the investor's $100,000 buys $500,000 or more of stock if he wants.

meanings.definition: to use something that you already have in order to achieve something new or better:
examples: We can gain a market advantage by leveraging our network of partners.

meanings.definition: to use borrowed money to buy an investment or company:
examples: Home equity is invaluable if you leverage it to build wealth.

meanings.definition: to use money to get more money:
examples: One of the easiest ways to leverage a charitable gift is to get your employer to match it.

meanings.definition: the power to influence results:
examples: financial/political leverage
The US has very little leverage in that part of the world.

meanings.definition: to use borrowed money for investments, esp. in order to buy a large enough part of a business so that you can control it:
examples: They can leverage a very small investment into millions of dollars.

meanings.definition: the power to influence people and get the results you want:
examples: This gives advertisers more leverage when it comes time to negotiate rates.
Campaigners are trying to get as much political leverage on the situation as possible.
States do not have the economic leverage to influence a foreign country.
Labor experts say a service economy can give leverage to unionized workers.

meanings.definition: the relationship between the amount of money that a company owes and its share capital or value:
examples: The company plans to reduce the leverage to between 40% and 60% by the year end.
The bank was asked to improve its capitalization and reduce its leverage.
The figure shows that they had high growth rates of bank lending and high leverage.
Even if banks were able to rush back into heavy leverage soon, investors wouldn't stand for it.

meanings.definition: the act of using borrowed money to buy an investment or a company:
examples: With leverage, the investor's $100,000 buys $500,000 or more of stock if he wants.

meanings.definition: to use something that you already have, such as a resource, in order to achieve something new or better:
examples: This new strategy is about leveraging the relationships we have with our customers.
If you enjoy the work, it should be possible to leverage your temporary assignment into a full-time job.

meanings.definition: to use borrowed money to buy an investment or a company:
examples: The money could be used to leverage millions of additional dollars.

meanings.definition: to increase the amount of money borrowed:
examples: He wanted them to leverage up the company and buy back some stock.
Hedge funds routinely leverage themselves up to surprisingly high levels.

meanings.definition: A leveraged company or organization owes a large amount of money in relation to its value:
examples: The company is highly leveraged and struggling with interest payments.

meanings.definition: A leveraged deal or investment has been paid for using borrowed money. :
examples: He owns some highly leveraged investment property.
The company was acquired by a consortium in a highly leveraged takeover.

meanings.definition: used to describe a company or organization that owes a large amount of money in relation to its value:
examples: Like other theater chains, it will be a highly leveraged company, carrying about $550 million in debt.

meanings.definition: used to describe an investment which has been bought with a large amount of borrowed money:
examples: They will have to reduce costs significantly to pay the borrowings to finance the highly leveraged deal.

meanings.definition: an occasion when a small company buys a larger one using money borrowed against the value of the equipment, buildings, etc. of both companies
an occasion when a person or group uses borrowed money to buy a company:
examples: Should such an offer emerge it would be the largest leveraged buyout in UK corporate history.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a company buys another by using borrowed money:
examples: He launched his proposal for the leveraged takeover last month.

examples: She levered up the drain cover.

meanings.definition: If you lever someone or something to a place, you move them there with great physical effort:
examples: He levered himself out of his chair with the usual difficulty and opened his arms wide.
Jim fought to pull himself up, levering his arms down.

meanings.definition: to change a situation in order to suit yourself, often using unfair methods:
examples: The company gobbles up rivals or levers them out of the market.

meanings.definition: someone who helps clients decide what they want in their life and how to achieve it:

meanings.definition: the job or activity of giving people advice about how to improve their lives:

meanings.definition: the length of time that a living thing, especially a human being, is likely to live:
examples: Life expectancy in Europe increased greatly in the 20th century.

meanings.definition: the average length of the life of members of a group of people or animals
the length of time that a person is likely to live:
examples: Life expectancy is the major factor influencing senior life insurance premiums.

meanings.definition: the length of time that something such as an electrical product is likely to last:
examples: As technology becomes more sophisticated, the life expectancy of household gadgets seems to diminish.

meanings.definition: any living thing:
examples: They are searching for intelligent life forms in other solar systems.

meanings.definition: an amount of money that is paid to and invested by insurance companies for life insurance, and from which money is paid when someone dies:
examples: It will use part of the life fund to distribute an average £500 of shares to policy holders.

meanings.definition: all the things that happen during the life of a living thing
the punishment of being put in prison for a very long time without an arranged time for release or, in the US, until death

a system in which you make regular payments to an insurance company in exchange for a fixed amount of money that will be paid to you when you reach a certain age, or paid to someone you have named, usually a member of your family, when you die
a system in which you make regular payments to an insurance company in exchange for a fixed amount of money that will be paid after you die to someone you chose

a system in which you make regular payments to an insurance company in exchange for a fixed amount of money which will be paid to someone you have named, usually a member of your family, when you die:
examples: For £23 a month a man aged 30 can buy a £100,000 life insurance policy.
a life insurance company

life-is-just-a-bowl-of-cherries.name: life is just a bowl of cherries

meanings.definition: something that you say that means that life is very pleasant. This phrase is often used humorously to mean the opposite.
a piece of equipment, like a jacket without sleeves, that is filled with air or light material and is designed to help you float if you fall into water
a piece of equipment that looks like a jacket without sleeves and that is filled with air or light material designed to help someone float if the person falls into the water
in the UK, a person who is given the honour of a title such as "Lord" and a place in the House of Lords as a reward for the good things they have done for the country

a type of boat that is carried on a large ship and is used in emergencies, for example when the ship is sinking, to take people to safety
one of the types of science that deal with the structure and behaviour of living things, such as botany, zoology, biochemistry, and anthropology
the punishment of being put in prison for a very long time, or, in the US, until death
something that will make a person suffer for the rest of their life:

meanings.definition: a skill that is useful or important in everyone's life:

meanings.definition: everything that has happened to someone during their life:

meanings.definition: the equipment used to keep a dangerously ill person alive

meanings.definition: If you describe something as life-affirming, you mean that it makes you feel positive about life:

meanings.definition: having an effect that is strong enough to change someone's life:

meanings.definition: involving the possibility that someone will die:

meanings.definition: very important and serious:

meanings.definition: having an effect that is strong enough to change someone's life:

meanings.definition: necessary for life or giving energy
(of a medical condition) reducing the length of time that a person is expected to live:
examples: The patients they care for have life-limiting illnesses that often involve physical and emotional suffering.

meanings.definition: the highest level reached during a particular futures contract (= a financial contract that must be bought or sold on an agreed future date at an agreed price):

meanings.definition: done to prevent someone from dying:

meanings.definition: actions that can save someone's life when they have fallen into water:

meanings.definition: A life-sized work of art or model is the same size as the person or thing that it represents:
examples: a life-size statue of an elephant

meanings.definition: (of statues, models, etc.) having the same size as the person or thing that it represents:
examples: a life-size plastic manikin

meanings.definition: the equipment used to keep a person alive when they are very ill, or injured:

meanings.definition: the natural structures and systems that are necessary for living things, especially humans, to be able to live:

meanings.definition: A life-threatening disease is a very serious one that can cause death:

meanings.definition: able to cause death:

meanings.definition: a piece of equipment, usually a ring filled with air or light material that floats, designed to help you float if you fall into water
the thing that is most important to the continuing success and existence of something else:
examples: Tourism is the lifeblood of Hawaii's economy.

meanings.definition: the thing that is most important to the continuing success and existence of something else:
examples: Tourism is the lifeblood of Hawaii’s economy.

meanings.definition: the most important thing that someone or something needs in order to continue to exist or operate:

meanings.definition: a large boat that is kept ready to go out and save people who are in danger in the water
a small boat kept on a ship for people to leave in if the ship is not safe or might sink
a large boat that is kept ready to take out to sea and save people who are in danger, or a smaller boat kept on a ship for people to leave in if the ship is not safe or might sink
something such as money or a plan that will help people or organizations who risk failing, losing all their money, etc.:

meanings.definition: a person on a beach or at a swimming pool whose job is to make certain that the swimmers are safe and save them if they are in danger

dead:

meanings.definition: showing little energy or interest:

meanings.definition: dead or appearing to be dead:

meanings.definition: in a way that shows someone is dead or makes someone look dead:

meanings.definition: in a way that shows little energy or interest:

meanings.definition: something, especially a way of getting help, that you depend on to lead your life in a satisfactory way:

meanings.definition: a rope that is thrown to someone who is in the water, especially the sea, and is in danger
something, esp. a way of getting help, on which you depend:

meanings.definition: lasting for the whole of a person’s life:
