someone who eats/drinks/smokes only a little:
examples: The recipe will feed eight light eaters or six hungry people.
If you are a light eater, I recommend snacking on Vietnamese summer rolls.
I am only a light drinker and my husband doesn't drink alcohol at all.
Even light smokers are more at risk of lung cancer than non-smokers.
I am a light smoker but I do enjoy a cigarette after a meal.

meanings.definition: the building of small machines or equipment:
examples: Light engineering factories have taken over the empty food-processing plants.

meanings.definition: television shows, plays, films, etc. that can be enjoyed without a lot of mental effort:
examples: Strictly Come Dancing became the BBC's most popular light entertainment show.
He was invited to lunch by a TV station's head of light entertainment.

meanings.definition: a rounded glass container with a thin thread of metal inside which produces light when an electric current goes through it
a boxer whose weight is between middleweight and heavyweight, or this division of boxing weight:
examples: He had been a successful light heavyweight in his youth.
He won the National Golden Gloves last month by defeating the defending light heavyweight champion.
the winner of the light heavyweight title
In the Senior Competition he will compete at lightheavyweight.

meanings.definition: relating to light industry:
examples: The site is being redeveloped for light industrial use.
Their property includes office buildings, light industrial facilities and apartment complexes.
light industrial goods/products

meanings.definition: industry that makes small things and does not need to use large, heavy machinery
industries that manufacture small equipment, clothing, electronics, etc.:
examples: One area has numerous coal-fired power plants and high levels of air pollution, the other is an area with light industry and lower levels of air pollution.

meanings.definition: a device for measuring how much light there is, especially when taking a photograph
to find or think of something unexpectedly:
examples: We lighted upon the solution entirely by accident.

meanings.definition: a pen-shaped device for making lines, writing, etc. appear on a computer screen:
examples: You can draw on the tablet screen using a light pen.
The pad uses a lightpen to "write" data directly onto the screen.

meanings.definition: a pen-shaped device used for reading bar codes:
examples: You access the system simply by moving a light pen across the bar code.

meanings.definition: a pen-shaped object that uses beams of light to read bar codes (= small rectangular patterns of printed lines that store data) or that you use to touch a computer screen in order to choose information:
examples: Outgoing inventory can be quickly checked with light pens connected to each terminal.

meanings.definition: unwanted artificial light that has a negative effect on the environment:
examples: Light pollution has changed the way we see the sky.
Outdoor lighting will be controlled to reduce light pollution.

meanings.definition: a railway system for transporting people around cities:
examples: They argued that we should put light rail through as many suburbs as possible.
The study found that metropolitan areas had lower emissions when they invested in light rail.

meanings.definition: a railway system for transporting people around a particular city:
examples: A subway system and a light railway is under construction.
There is a growing interest in light railways as a cheap, energy-efficient transport solution in urban areas.

meanings.definition: someone who is easily woken up by noise, etc.:
examples: I'm a very light sleeper.
He was a light sleeper and woke every time a train went by.
She was a light sleeper who found it difficult to get back to sleep.
Her baby was such a light sleeper, he woke up whenever she entered the room.
I am a light sleeper but I didn't hear anything.

meanings.definition: the speed at which light travels in a vacuum (= a space in which there is no matter):
examples: Light speed is considered to be the maximum speed for any particle to travel according to known physical laws.
Magnets propel streams of electrons around the track, accelerating them to near light-speed.

meanings.definition: an extremely fast speed:
examples: Rumours spread around here at light speed.
Everything seems to be changing faster than light speed at the moment.
She works at a light-speed pace.

meanings.definition: to score a goal in ice hockey:
examples: He lit the lamp 48 times last season, the most on the team.
He provided a thrill to the home crowd by lighting the lamp with just under two minutes left in the game.

meanings.definition: to make a bad or extreme situation start happening or to make someone react in an angry or extreme way:
examples: The president was fearful of lighting a touchpaper that could spark greater unrest.
It takes a lot to light the blue touchpaper, but when I blow, duck.

meanings.definition: the use of light to treat medical conditions, especially skin problems or mental health problems:
examples: Light therapy involves sitting under bright, artificial light emitted from a box or lamp for about 30 minutes a day.
His psoriasis went into remission for two years after his initial treatment with light therapy.
Winter depression can be treated with antidepressants or light therapy.

meanings.definition: a friendly, relaxed, or humourous way of doing something:
examples: She brings a light touch to the office hiring rituals, which makes everyone feel comfortable.

meanings.definition: a situation in which only a few people are in charge of something or something is not controlled very strictly:
examples: I think we have five account managers covering the whole United States, so it's a light touch.
The report endorses the 'light touch' regulatory environment outlined in the bill.

meanings.definition: the distance that light travels in one year (about 9.5 million million kilometres)
the great distance that light travels in one year; about 5,880,000,000,000 miles or 9,460,000,000,000 kilometers
People sometimes say light years to talk about an extremely long distance or time:
examples: When I was a young man, being 50 seemed light years away.

meanings.definition: an extremely long time from now in the past or future:
examples: It all happened when I was at college, which seems light years away now that I'm over 50.

meanings.definition: used to describe vehicles that are designed to carry fairly light loads (= amounts of weight):
examples: Light-duty trucks cost less and use less gasoline than heavy-duty ones.

meanings.definition: used for describing work that involves less physical activity than the usual type:
examples: Many employers don't provide light-duty work, which makes it difficult for an employee to return to work after an operation.

meanings.definition: If you describe someone as light-fingered, you mean that they have a habit of stealing things.
If you feel light-headed, you feel weak and as if you are going to lose your balance:
examples: She'd had a couple of glasses of champagne and was starting to feel light-headed.

meanings.definition: with a feeling that you may fall over or become unconscious:
examples: Her back ached, her hands were blistered, and she was starving, yet she felt light-headedly happy.
I wondered, lightheadedly, what she would think if I told her that the note was an attempt on her husband's life.

meanings.definition: happy and not serious:
examples: It was a fairly light-hearted discussion.

meanings.definition: not thinking seriously or being serious about anything:
examples: She was warm-hearted and light-minded, but could also be remarkably stubborn.
He betrays a lightminded attitude towards economic problems.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows someone does not think seriously or is not serious about anything:
examples: How could he write so lightmindedly that the revolution would automatically solve its own problems?
The Central Committee makes baseless attacks upon the militants of the cadres and replaces them light-mindedly.

meanings.definition: burning or starting to burn:
examples: a lighted candle/match
a lighted fuse

meanings.definition: to become less dark:
examples: The sky had lightened and there were breaks in the clouds.

meanings.definition: to make something lighter:
examples: The sun always lightens my hair.

meanings.definition: to (cause to) become happier and less worried:
examples: His mood lightened after the phone call.
He tried to lighten the atmosphere by telling a joke.

meanings.definition: to make someone or become happier and less anxious:
examples: Being with friends lightened her mood.

meanings.definition: to reduce the weight of something:
examples: He lost 30 pounds to lighten the burden on his knee.

meanings.definition: To lighten is also to make an amount of work or a responsibility less heavy:
examples: To lighten the load, he decided to divide the job between two people.

meanings.definition: to make a difficult situation or responsibility easier:
examples: Getting a new assistant will lighten (= reduce) the workload considerably.
If elected, we will lighten the regulatory burden on small businesses.
College fees are high, but scholarships and grants can lighten the burden.
These measures do little to lighten the load of social workers.
If you could take care of the children today, that would help lighten my load.

meanings.definition: to make a speech or piece of writing less serious:
examples: I thought I'd slip in a few jokes to lighten up the talk.

meanings.definition: to become more relaxed and less serious:
examples: Oh, lighten up! I was only joking!
I wish she'd just lighten up.

meanings.definition: stop being so serious:
examples: Why don’t you just relax and enjoy yourself? Lighten up!

examples: The sun always lightens my hair.

examples: His mood lightened after the phone call.

meanings.definition: a small device for providing a flame for a cigarette, etc.:
examples: a cigarette lighter

meanings.definition: a low, open boat used to move goods to and from ships in a harbour:
examples: Fishing boats, barges and lighters were busy around the ships.
All supplies are offloaded onto lighters.

meanings.definition: a small device that provides a flame

a man who works on a lighter (= a low, open boat used to move goods to and from ships in a harbour) or on a barge (= a long boat with a flat bottom, used for carrying heavy objects on rivers or canals):
examples: After a seven-year apprenticeship he qualified as waterman and lighterman on the Thames.
Like many lightermen, Captain Andrews followed his father and grandfather into the trade.

meanings.definition: having a feeling that you may fall over or become unconscious:
examples: If I don’t eat something at lunchtime I start to feel lightheaded by midafternoon.

meanings.definition: amusing and not serious:
examples: The documentary takes a lighthearted look at the world of filmmaking.

meanings.definition: in a way that is happy and not serious:
examples: The documentary starts out lightheartedly enough but the tone soon darkens.
"You don't want to believe all that gossip,'" he said light-heartedly.

meanings.definition: a tall building near the coast or shore with a flashing light at the top to warn ships of rocks and other dangers
a tall structure by the sea with a flashing light that warns ships of dangerous rocks or shows them the way into a port
the arrangement of lights used in a room, house, theatre, etc.
the lights in a room or on a stage, or the effects of those lights:
examples: The lighting in the living room is too dim.

meanings.definition: the type and arrangement of lights used in place:
examples: Emergency lighting shows the way to the exits.
We'll offer to totally replace all your lighting with energy-efficient lighting.

meanings.definition: the time in the afternoon or evening when the law states that vehicles must have their lights switched on
gently:
examples: She patted him lightly on the shoulder.
He touched me lightly on the cheek.
Dab the paint on lightly.

meanings.definition: to only a small degree:
examples: Bake the cookies for 6-8 minutes, or until lightly browned.
Online gambling is only lightly regulated.
Wine labelled "frizzante" is lightly sparkling.

meanings.definition: If food is lightly cooked, it is cooked for only a short time:
examples: lightly cooked vegetables
I like eggs lightly cooked so that the yolk is still runny.

meanings.definition: If you say something lightly, you are not serious when you say it:
examples: "Anyway, it won't affect me because I'm leaving," she said lightly.

meanings.definition: without serious consideration:
examples: Funding for public schools is something I don't take lightly.

meanings.definition: If food is lightly cooked, it is cooked for only a short time.
the state of being light
a flash of bright light in the sky that is produced by electricity moving between clouds or from clouds to the ground:
examples: thunder and lightning
a flash/bolt of lightning
That tree was struck by lightning.
She changed her clothes with lightning speed (= extremely quickly).

meanings.definition: a flash of bright light in the sky produced by electricity moving within or between clouds, or between clouds and the ground:
examples: That tree was struck by lightning in a recent thunderstorm.

meanings.definition: very fast:
examples: She moves at lightning speed.

meanings.definition:
a 
        
         firefly
a firefly

a strip of metal, going from the highest point of a building to the ground, that prevents lightning from damaging the building by taking the electricity to the ground before it can reach a dangerous level
someone or something that takes all the blame or criticism in a situation, although other people or things are responsible too:
examples: In a harsh economic climate, pay rises for politicians have become a lightning conductor for criticism.

meanings.definition: said to show that it is unlikely that something bad or unusual will happen to the same person twice

a strip of metal, going from the highest point of a building to the ground, that prevents lightning from damaging the building by taking the electricity to the ground before it can reach a dangerous level
someone or something that takes all the blame or criticism in a situation, although other people or things are responsible too:
examples: In a harsh economic climate, raises for politicians have become a lightning rod for criticism.

meanings.definition: a strip of metal that prevents lightning from damaging a building by directing the electricity into the ground
someone who attracts criticism or anger that could be directed at someone else:
examples: Darman continues to be the White House's lightning rod, drawing criticism from conservatives.

meanings.definition: an occasion when lightning (= a flash of bright light in the sky that is produced by electricity moving between clouds or from clouds to the ground) hits something:
examples: The fire was caused by a lightning strike.
With so many thunderstorms at this time of year, lightning strikes are a risk.

meanings.definition: a sudden and unexpected event, idea, etc.:
examples: Suddenly, out of the blue, John has a lightning strike of inspiration.
The success of the book is explicable with hindsight, but at the time it was the classic example of a literary lightning strike.

meanings.definition: a sudden strike (= an act of refusing to work as a protest) without any warning and often without the official support of a trade union:
examples: Workers from three car plants staged lightning strikes.
His sacking sparked a lightning strike by around 1,200 postal workers.

meanings.definition: a situation where employees stop work suddenly and without warning because of a disagreement with their employer about job conditions, job losses, pay, etc.:
examples: Union representatives called a lightning strike over a deadlock with the railway.

meanings.definition: a talk to a group of people that is about five minutes long and includes slides (= individual pages of information on a computer screen) or video:
examples: The most popular sessions of the entire conference are the lightning talks.
In addition to the lightning talks, we'll have a number of meatier discussions and breakout sessions in smaller groups.

meanings.definition: (at a school where children live or in the army) the time in the evening when the lights are switched off in the room where people sleep:
examples: No talking after lights-out!

meanings.definition: a small ship with a flashing light on it, that stays in one place to warn ships of rocks and other dangers:
examples: Barnegat Lighthouse, built in 1855, was replaced in 1930 by an offshore lightship.
The light ship had to radio for a lifeboat after it was hit by a steamship in thick fog.

meanings.definition: happy and without worries:
examples: Their lightsome hearts know nothing of those bleak days, when the beautiful city lay in ashes.

meanings.definition: weighing only a little or less than average:
examples: I need a lightweight jacket for the summer evenings.

meanings.definition: not showing deep understanding or knowledge of any subject:
examples: She's the author of some fairly lightweight historical novels.

meanings.definition: a boxer who weighs more than a featherweight but less than a welterweight, or this division of boxing weight:
examples: He had taken gold as a lightweight at the 1992 Barcelona Olympics.
He was the defending world lightweight champion.
He stopped the Irish boxer in the 12th round to retain the WBC lightweight title.
In Athens he won the silver medal at lightweight.

meanings.definition: a person or thing that is not very serious and that other people do not consider to be important:
examples: In certain circles he has been dismissed as a literary lightweight.
He was seen by some as a bit of a lightweight who did not seem to stand for anything.

meanings.definition: someone who is unable to drink much alcohol without being affected by it or made ill:
examples: He's such a lightweight - two drinks and he's completely gone.
I just had a couple of drinks, nothing too mad. I'm a bit of a lightweight.

meanings.definition: (esp. of clothes) weighing little and therefore not warm:
examples: a lightweight jacket

meanings.definition: (of a person) of little importance, or (of ideas) created without serious thought or purpose:
examples: The movie was a lightweight comedy.

meanings.definition: a person of little importance, or an idea created without serious thought or purpose:
weighing only a little or less than average:
examples: We shipped thousands of very lightweight cardigans for the spring season.
Composites tend to be stronger than steel but more lightweight.
lightweight plastics/carbon fibres

meanings.definition: not showing deep understanding, knowledge, or ability:
examples: She's the author of some fairly lightweight investing guides.
Many in the US regarded him as too lightweight to become the IMF's managing director.

meanings.definition: someone who does not show deep understanding, knowledge, or ability:
examples: In certain circles he has been dismissed as an intellectual lightweight.

meanings.definition: hard and like wood, because of containing lignin
a substance found in the edges of some plant cells that makes the plant hard like wood
an evergreen tree (= one that never loses its leaves) from the West Indies:
examples: Lignum vitae is indigenous to the West Indies and grows up to 30ft.
Some of the best wood carvings are made from the lignum vitae, the Bahamian national tree.

meanings.definition: the very hard wood of the lignum vitae tree, used in building and to make wooden objects:
examples: Most types of wood will float on water but some, including lignum vitae, will sink.
The fort was built in the mid-1700s, using mahogany and the notoriously hard tropical wood lignum vitae.

meanings.definition:
mainly US spelling of 
        
         likeable
easy to like:
examples: Cassius was a likable, friendly youngster.

meanings.definition: to enjoy or approve of something or someone:
examples: I like your new haircut.
Do you like fish?
I like it when a book is so good that you can't put it down.
I quite like wine but I could live without it.
He's very well-liked (= popular) at work.
I like the way he just assumes we'll listen to him when he doesn't take in a word anyone else says! (= I don't like it and it annoys me.)
I don't like upsetting people.
He likes to spend his evenings in front of the television.
He likes his steak well-done.

meanings.definition: to show that you think something is good on a social networking website by clicking on a symbol or the word 'like':
examples: Like us on Facebook!
More than 200 people liked my post.

meanings.definition: used in requests:
examples: I'd like one of the round loaves, please.
I'd like to book a seat for tonight's performance.
I'd like you to send this for me, please.
I would like the whole lot finished by the weekend.

meanings.definition: similar to; in the same way or manner as:
examples: He looks like his brother.
She's very much like her mother (= she is similar in appearance or character).
Is Japanese food like Chinese?
I've got a sweater just like that.
Her hair was so soft it was like silk.
You're acting like a complete idiot!
She sings like an angel!
Like I said (= as I have already said), I don't wear perfume.
Like most people (= as most people would), I'd prefer to have enough money not to work.
It feels/seems like (= it seems to me) ages since we last spoke.
There's nothing like a good cup of coffee (= it's better than anything)!

meanings.definition: in a way that suggests:
examples: It looks like I'm going to be in the office until late tonight.
It looks like rain (= I think it is going to rain).
It sounds to me like you ought to change jobs.
You look like you've just got out of bed!
She acts like she's stupid!

meanings.definition: typical or characteristic of:
examples: That's just like Maisie to turn up half an hour late to her own party!
It's not like you to be so quiet - are you all right, my love?

meanings.definition: such as:
examples: She looks best in bright, vibrant colours, like red and pink.

meanings.definition: used before you describe how you were feeling or what you said when something happened to you:
examples: Then I saw how late it was and I'm like, so upset.
He started shouting at me and I'm like, "What's your problem? I'm on your side!"

meanings.definition: used in conversation as a pause or to emphasize an adjective:
examples: He's, like, really friendly - someone you can talk to.
If there's nothing you can do to change the situation, it's like - why bother?

meanings.definition: (on a page on a social networking website) an act of showing that you think something is good by clicking a button:
examples: My new profile picture got 100 likes.

meanings.definition: similar to, or the same as, something else:
examples: It's good to be surrounded by people with like minds.
Maybe my employer expects me to respond to his bantering in a like manner.

meanings.definition: The like poles (= ends) of a magnet (= an object that both attracts and pushes away iron and steel objects) are the ends which have the same charge (= negative or positive type of energy) and repel (= push away) each other:
examples: Like poles repel, unlike poles attract.

meanings.definition: like the thing mentioned:
examples: The paper criticized what it described as the animal-like behaviour of the fans.
There was a large, ball-like structure on top of the building.
childlike trust
a cabbage-like vegetable

meanings.definition: to enjoy or approve of something or someone, or to prefer something a particular way:
examples: I like your new haircut.
Do you like fish?
I like taking my time in the morning.
I like my music loud.

meanings.definition: Like can be used with "how" when asking for someone’s reaction to something:
examples: How do you like my new shoes?

meanings.definition: to want something:
examples: I’d like the chicken soup, please.
The commissioner would like to say thanks to everyone who’s helped.
Would you like (= Do you want) something to drink?

meanings.definition: similar to; in the same way or manner as:
examples: I’ve got a sweater just like yours.
Stop acting like a jerk!
She looks just like her father.
infmlLike I said (= As I already said), I’m not interested in buying insurance at the moment.

meanings.definition: If you ask what something is like, you are asking someone to describe it or compare it to something:
examples: What’s your new job like?
What does it taste like?

meanings.definition: as if it will or was; in a way that suggests:
examples: It looks like rain.
It sounds to me like you ought to change jobs.

meanings.definition: someone similar to another person or something similar to another thing:
examples: Planners unveiled designs for a multibillion-dollar cultural district whose like has never been seen before.

meanings.definition: willing to; in the mood for:
examples: I don’t feel like going out tonight.

meanings.definition: typical or characteristic of; to be expected of:
examples: It’s not like you to be so quiet – are you all right?

meanings.definition: such as; for example:
examples: I prefer natural fabrics like cotton and wool.
Alonzo is not the kind of guy who would do something like this.

meanings.definition: used in conversation to emphasize what follows, or when you cannot express your exact meaning:
examples: He’s, like, really friendly – someone you can talk to.
It was, like, getting pretty late but I didn’t want to go home yet.

meanings.definition: Like is also used in conversation to introduce someone else’s words or your own words:
examples: So I’m telling Patti about my class and she’s like, No way, and I’m like, It happened.

meanings.definition: used to say that someone does something very well:
examples: I'm going to teach you to draw like a boss.

like-a-bull-in-a-china-shop.name: like a bull in a china shop

meanings.definition: If someone is like a bull in a china shop, they are very careless in the way that they move or behave:
examples: We told her it was a delicate situation but she went into the meeting like a bull in a china shop.

like-a-cat-on-a-hot-tin-roof.name: like a cat on a hot tin roof

meanings.definition: used to describe someone who is in a state of extreme nervous worry

like-a-dog-with-two-tails.name: like a dog with two tails

meanings.definition: used to say that someone is very happy about something:
examples: Lucy will be like a dog with two tails if she gets into the team.

meanings.definition: very quickly:
examples: The medicine went through me like a dose of salts.

like-a-lamb-to-the-slaughter.name: like a lamb to the slaughter

meanings.definition: If someone does something or goes somewhere like a lamb to the slaughter, they do it without knowing that something bad is going to happen and therefore act calmly and without fighting against the situation.
in a wild and uncontrolled way:
examples: He's been running around the office this morning like a man possessed.

meanings.definition: If someone works like a maniac, they work extremely hard.

like-a-shag-on-a-rock.name: like a shag on a rock

meanings.definition: completely alone
When someone does something like a shot, they do it extremely quickly and enthusiastically:
examples: The moment I let go of the dog, she's off like a shot.

meanings.definition: (of someone's mind or memory) very sharp and quick to understand or remember things:
examples: She is an incredible investigative researcher who has a mind like a steel trap.
His relaxed manner conceals a mind like a steel trap.
At 82 he still has a twinkle in his eyes and a memory like a steel trap.

meanings.definition: extremely quickly:
examples: She grabbed the money and ran out of the shop like a streak of lightning.

like-a-thief-in-the-night.name: like a thief in the night

meanings.definition: secretly or unexpectedly and without being seen
very strongly or forcefully:
examples: If Dad finds out what you've been doing, he'll come down on (= punish) you like a ton of bricks!

meanings.definition: very much or very hard:
examples: The wind blew and it was raining like blazes.
The dogs started barking like blazes.
I'm going to work like blazes to make you proud.

meanings.definition: very regularly, or at exactly the planned times:
examples: Since the recent improvements to the service, the buses are running like clockwork.
My daughter always calls me every Friday evening, (as) regular as clockwork.

meanings.definition: exactly as planned:
examples: So far, everything had worked like clockwork.

meanings.definition: If you do something like crazy, you do a lot of it or do it very quickly:
examples: They were working like crazy to get the job done on time.

meanings.definition: a lot or very quickly:
examples: Mark’s working like crazy to get the house painted by the end of the week.

meanings.definition: used to describe a drink or liquid that is unpleasant because it contains too much water and has very little flavour:
examples: This tea tastes like dishwater.

meanings.definition: with great energy and determination:
examples: I've been working like fury these past few days to catch up.

meanings.definition: said about something that is very difficult to get because a lot of people want it:
examples: Tickets for the concert are like gold dust.

meanings.definition: very fast:
examples: As soon as I mentioned work, he was out of the door like greased lightning!

meanings.definition: very much: certainly not:
examples: We ran like hell.
We worked like hell to finish the job.
It hurt like hell.
"Try to be polite to him." "Like hell I will!"

meanings.definition: used to describe something that is extremely difficult to do:
examples: He says managing lawyers is like herding cats.
"It's like herding cats sometimes", she said of the logistical challenges.

meanings.definition: If you tell someone to like it or lump it, you mean that person must accept a situation they do not like, because it cannot be changed:
examples: Like it or lump it, romantic fiction is read regularly by thousands.

like-it-s-going-out-of-fashion.name: like it's going out of fashion

meanings.definition: If you use something like it's going out of fashion, you use large amounts of it very quickly:
examples: Emma spends money like it's going out of fashion.
Unfortunately, the truck drinks petrol like it's going out of fashion.
The managers bought shares like it was going out of fashion.
I was slapping on sunscreen like it was going out of fashion.
He isn't the only star to spend money like it's going out of fashion.

meanings.definition: in a silly way, without thinking, and in large numbers:
examples: People rushed like lemmings to invest in the company.

meanings.definition: extremely quickly
If you do something like mad, you do it very enthusiastically, quickly, or a lot:
examples: She's been saving like mad because she wants to buy a car.

meanings.definition: very quickly or very much:
examples: He was scribbling away like nobody's business.

meanings.definition: very strange, unusual, or unpleasant:
examples: With his make-up and strange clothes, he looked like nothing on earth.

meanings.definition: very strange, unusual, or unpleasant in appearance, sound, or taste:
examples: It looked nice, but it tasted like nothing on earth.

meanings.definition: If you say that making someone do something was like pulling teeth, you mean it was very difficult and they did not want to do it:
examples: Getting her to tell me about her childhood was like pulling teeth.

like-rats-leaving-a-sinking-ship.name: like rats leaving a sinking ship

meanings.definition: used to refer to people leaving a place, organization, activity, etc. very quickly and in large numbers, because it is failing in some way:
examples: Former friends have deserted the couple like rats leaving a sinking ship.
His aides could finally depart for lucrative private sector jobs without looking like rats deserting a sinking ship.

like-ships-that-pass-in-the-night.name: like ships that pass in the night

meanings.definition: If two people are like ships that pass in the night, they meet once or twice by chance for a short time then do not see each other again.
If someone works like stink, they work extremely hard.

like-the-cat-that-ate-the-canary.name: like the cat that ate the canary

meanings.definition: extremely happy or satisfied, or in a very happy or satisfied way:
examples: When he asked her on a date she was like the cat that ate the canary.

like-the-cat-that-got-the-cream.name: like the cat that got the cream

meanings.definition: extremely happy or satisfied, or in a very happy or satisfied way:
examples: She looks like the cat that got the cream.

meanings.definition: extremely fast:

meanings.definition: to feel happy or satisfied about a piece of information you have just heard:
examples: "The radio says there’ll be rain turning into snow." "Ooh, I don’t like the sound of that."

meanings.definition: very quickly:
examples: Alice ran like the wind.

meanings.definition: If someone does something like there is no tomorrow, they do it very fast or a lot and without thinking carefully:
examples: After he won the lottery, he began spending money like there was no tomorrow.

meanings.definition: as much or as fast as possible, without planning or thinking first:

like-two-peas-in-a-pod.name: like two peas in a pod

meanings.definition: very similar, especially in appearance:

meanings.definition: quickly in a way that cannot be controlled:
examples: News of the layoffs spread like wildfire through the company.

like-you-care-like-you-d-know-like-he-d-.name: like you care!/like you'd know!/like he'd ask!

meanings.definition: used to emphasize that something that has been suggested is not true or would never happen:

meanings.definition: in a way that is too confident:
examples: He walked into the office like he owned the place.

meanings.definition: criticisms of or warnings to a particular person that have no effect on that person:
examples: I've told him that he's heading for trouble, but he doesn't listen - it's just water off a duck's back.

meanings.definition: like-for-like figures compare sales, financial results, etc. in one period with those for the previous period, taking into account exactly the same number of stores, businesses, activities, etc. with no new ones added:
examples: Sainsbury's like-for-like sales in the second quarter were up by 1.2% on the same period last year.

meanings.definition: used for describing something of the same value, quality, etc. that replaces a lost, stolen, or damaged possession:
examples: We will provide you with a like-for-like vehicle because we understand that if you are used to driving a high-performance car, you will not want to take a step downwards.

meanings.definition: figures that compare sales, financial results, etc. in one period with those for the previous period, taking into account exactly the same number of stores, businesses, activities, etc. with no new ones added:
examples: Their like-for-likes show a big improvement on last year.

meanings.definition: People who are described as like-minded share the same opinions, ideas, or interests:

meanings.definition: A likeable person is pleasant and easy to like:

meanings.definition: to control something so that it is not more than a particular amount, number, or level:

meanings.definition: If someone or something has limitations, that person or thing is not as good as they or it could be:

The literal meaning of a word is its original, basic meaning:
examples: The literal meaning of "television" is "seeing from a distance".
You will need to show more than just a literal understanding of the text.

meanings.definition: A literal translation of a text is done by translating each word separately, without looking at how the words are used together in a phrase or sentence:
examples: Her translation is too literal, resulting in unnatural-sounding prose.

meanings.definition: having exactly the same meaning as the basic or original meaning of a word or expression:
examples: a literal interpretation of the Constitution

meanings.definition: A literal translation of a phrase in another language gives the meaning of each separate word.
using the real or original meaning of a word or phrase:
examples: They were responsible for literally millions of deaths.

meanings.definition: If you translate literally, you translate each word in a text separately, without looking at how the words are used together in a phrase or sentence:

meanings.definition: used to emphasize what you are saying:
examples: He missed that kick literally by miles.

meanings.definition: simply or just:

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to literature :

examples: As you enter the lobby, you’ll see the elevators on your right.

meanings.definition: a group of people who represent a particular industry or interest in dealing with a politician, official, etc.:
examples: the environmental lobby

meanings.definition: to try to persuade an elected official to take a particular action or change a law:
examples: Council members have been lobbying colleagues on how to vote.

meanings.definition: to try to persuade someone in authority, usually an elected member of a government, to support laws or rules that give your organization or industry an advantage:
examples: He lobbies against restrictions on investment.
A coalition of business groups lobbied hard to have the legislation changed.
He said private schools would lobby the General Assembly to restore the funding.
After the fatal crash, safety experts blamed the fuel-tank design and lobbied to make the cars safer.

meanings.definition: a group of people that lobbies someone in authority:
examples: The leading employers' lobby called for less government regulation.
A powerful lobby of property companies and retailers is being formed.

The government is under pressure from business lobbies who want taxes on companies reduced.
environmental/farmer's/energy lobby

meanings.definition: a reporter who spends a lot of time in the British parliament trying to discover news about recent and future political events
the activity of trying to persuade someone in authority, usually an elected member of a government, to support laws or rules that give your organization or industry an advantage:
examples: In her speech she stressed that she is not involved in the firm's lobbying of Congress.
This week, a coalition of unions, religious groups and liberal advocacy organizations will officially begin its lobbying for a higher minimum wage.
There was intense lobbying against the measures by drug companies.
Lobbying efforts by high-powered tech firms turned former supporters of the bill against it.
lobbying firm/group/organization
lobbying costs/fees/expenditure

meanings.definition: someone who tries to persuade a politician or official group to do something:
examples: Lobbyists for the tobacco industry have expressed concerns about the restriction of smoking in public places.

meanings.definition: someone who lobbies people in positions of authority:
examples: Rutherford went to work as a consultant and lobbyist for the oil business.
the chief lobbyist for Harvard University
He is an industry lobbyist and former congressman.

meanings.definition: any part of an organ that seems to be separate in some way from the rest, especially one of the parts of the brain, lungs, or liver:
examples: the frontal lobe of the brain

a rounded or pointed part on a leaf that sticks out from the main part:

meanings.definition: an earlobe
(of a leaf) having rounded or pointed parts that stick out from the main part:
examples: The mature leaves are deeply lobed, often curling at the edges.
Some varieties have more handsomely lobed foliage than others.

meanings.definition: (of an organ such as the brain, lungs, or liver) having a part or parts that seem to be separate in some way from the rest:
examples: The pancreas is a small, white, lobed organ lying below the kidneys.

meanings.definition: a garden plant with blue, red, yellow, or white flowers that look like lips:
examples: Bright blue lobelias spilled out of pots by the front door.
Lobelia are beautiful delicate little bedding plants.

a medical operation in which cuts are made in or near the front part of the brain, used in the past for the treatment of severe mental problems
a stew or baked dish, eaten in the past by sailors, made from meat, vegetables, and hardtack (= a hard biscuit made from flour and water, given as food in the past to sailors and soldiers):
examples: He crumbled the hardtack into a pot of boiling lobscouse.
The lobscouse was usually made from leftover meat and vegetables.

meanings.definition: an animal that lives in the sea and has a long body covered with a hard shell, two large claws, and eight legs, or its flesh when used as food
an animal that lives in the sea and has a shell-like covering on its body, two large claws, and eight legs, or the flesh of this animal when used as food:
examples: We had lobster for dinner.

meanings.definition: a type of box made of wire used for catching lobsters
a dish of cooked lobster with a rich cream sauce, topped with cheese, and then grilled (= cooked under a very hot surface) in its shell:
examples: The restaurant serves bistro classics such as lobster thermidor.
The chef gave us tips on how to prepare the perfect lobster thermidor.

meanings.definition: having or relating to lobes (= parts that seem to be separate from the rest of the organ, etc.):
examples: This lobular appearance is characteristic of the presence of cartilage.
Lobular cancer accounts for about 15% of all invasive breast cancers.

meanings.definition: consisting of or divided into lobules (= small parts of an organ that seem to be separate from the rest):
examples: The mass was irregular, lobulated, and brown in colour.
The lingula head is distinctly lobulate, usually about as long as it is wide.

meanings.definition: the process in which tissue divides into or forms lobules (= small parts of an organ or tumour that seem to be separate from the rest), or the result of this process:
examples: One patient had lobulation of the right kidney in combination with renal calcification and renal stones.
Germ cell tumours showed a round mass without distinct lobulation.

meanings.definition: a small lobe (= a part of an organ that seems to be separate from the rest):
examples: Breast cancer forms in breast tissue, commonly arising in the ducts or lobules.

meanings.definition: a Latin word meaning "lobe" (= a part of an organ that seems to be separate from the rest), used in medical names and descriptions
used by writers to avoid repeating the details of a book or article that has already been referred to, when all the details, including the page number, are the same:
examples: See Wright, loc. cit.

meanings.definition: from, existing in, serving, or responsible for a small area, especially of a country:
examples: a local accent
local issues
a local newspaper/radio station
Most of the local population depend on fishing for their income.
Our children all go to the local school.
Many local shops will be forced to close if the new supermarket is built.

meanings.definition: limited to a particular part of the body:
examples: a local anaesthetic
local swelling

meanings.definition: a person who lives in the particular small area that you are talking about:
examples: The café is popular with both locals and visitors.

meanings.definition: a pub near to where a person lives, especially if they often go there to drink:
examples: The George is my local.

meanings.definition: a train or bus that makes all or most of the stops along its route, allowing passengers to get on or off:
examples: the 12.24 local to Poughkeepsie

meanings.definition: a division within a union representing people from a particular area
from, existing in, or serving a particular place or small area:
examples: the local population
the local newspaper
local phone calls
local government

meanings.definition: medical Local also means limited to a particular part of the body:
examples: a local anesthetic

meanings.definition: a train or bus that stops at all or most of the places on its route where passengers can get on or off
a person who lives in the particular small area you are talking about:
examples: If you’re lost and need directions, just ask one of the locals.

meanings.definition: from or connected with a particular area:
examples: The importation of goods from the United States has reduced growth in the local market.
US firms pay bonuses in dollars, in contrast to European rivals which tend to pay in local currency.
He has a four-month contract fixing computers at a local company.
This is a hugely serious problem at the local level, and we need to do something about it.

meanings.definition: a part of an organization, especially a union (= workers' organization), representing people from a particular area:
examples: The local in Oakland and Macomb has nearly 4,000 members.

meanings.definition: a drug that is used in medical procedures on or in a particular part of the body, so that you remain awake but do not feel any pain in that part:
examples: The procedure is carried out under local anaesthetic and sedation.
I was given a local anaesthetic and a small incision was made in my neck.

meanings.definition: a drug that is used in medical procedures on or in a particular part of the body, so that you remain awake but do not feel any pain in that part:
examples: This test is usually done in the hospital under local anesthetic.
The biopsy can be performed in the doctor's office with the use of a local anesthetic.

meanings.definition: a system for connecting the computers of people who work in the same building:
examples: The company supplies local area network equipment and technical support.

meanings.definition: the group of people who govern an area, especially a city
an official organization that is responsible for governing an area of the country:
examples: Kathryn works as a population researcher for a local authority.
A recent survey found that almost a third of the population is unhappy with local authority services.

meanings.definition: the special or unusual features of a place, especially as described or shown in a story, picture, or movie to make it seem more real
the special or unusual features of a place, especially as described or shown in a story, picture, or film to make it seem more real
the materials, workers, etc. used to make a product that are from the area where the product is made rather than being imported:
examples: All three car manufacturers claim that they use 60-80% local content.
The local content rules state that where imported parts account for more than 60% of the value of a final vehicle, those parts are taxed.

meanings.definition: the group of people elected to govern a region, city, town, etc. within a country and organize services for it:
examples: The local council has announced that the school will close at the end of the year.
The local council set up a committee to review arrangements for recycling.

meanings.definition: the currency that is used in a particular country:
examples: Gold has become cheaper to buy where local currencies have appreciated.
It's good to have some local currency available when you arrive in a new country.

meanings.definition: a sports competition, especially a game of football, between two teams from the same city or area
the control and organization of towns and small areas, and the services they provide, by people who are elected by those living in the area:
examples: We are asking both local and national government to address the issue of climate change.

meanings.definition: an individual organization that is responsible for controlling and organizing a town or small area, providing its services, etc.:
examples: The study looked at the role of local governments in the financial crisis.

meanings.definition: the control and organization of towns and small areas by an elected organization, or the organization itself:
examples: She is now running her own consultancy business after a career in local government.

meanings.definition: a tax paid to the government in a particular area:

meanings.definition: the official time in a country or an area
an area or place, especially one where something special happens, such as the action in a book or film:
examples: The book's locale is a coastal town in the summer of 1958.

meanings.definition: an area or place, esp. one where something special happens:

the idea that people should have control over what happens in their local area, that local businesses should be supported, and that differences between places should be respected:
examples: Mass media can work against the interests of localism and diversity.

meanings.definition: a particular area:
examples: Many people are opting to live in the city rather than in rural localities.

meanings.definition: a particular area or neighborhood:

meanings.definition: a particular area of a state or country:

meanings.definition: the process of organizing a business or industry so that its main activities happen in local areas rather than nationally or internationally:
examples: In under 20 years, the number of breweries in America has risen from 44 to 2,000, nearly all of which are small-scale. A similar localisation of brewing is happening in Britain.
The localization process is starting with the rapid growth of farmers' markets selling local produce.

meanings.definition: the process of making a product or service more suitable for a particular country, area, etc.:
examples: Technology has taken television meteorology to a whole new level of localization and accuracy.

meanings.definition: to limit something to a particular area:

meanings.definition: to find the position of something:

meanings.definition: to make a product or service more suitable for a particular area:

meanings.definition: to organize a business or industry so that its main activities happen in local areas rather than nationally or internationally:

meanings.definition: to make a product or service more suitable for a particular country, area, etc.:

meanings.definition: happening in or limited to a particular area:

meanings.definition: a national park (= a large area of land protected by the government because of its natural beauty or because it has a special history) in the central part of Scotland:
examples: The Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park lies close to Scotland's heavily populated Central Belt, and the area has long been popular with visitors.
Here in Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park, we have plenty of wee hills that offer spectacular views in exchange for minimum effort.

safety locks

something that is certain to happen:
examples: She's a lock for promotion this year.

meanings.definition: a small group of hairs, especially a curl:
examples: There is a lock of Napoleon's hair in the display cabinet.

meanings.definition: the amount a road vehicle's front wheels can be turned from one side to the other by turning its steering wheel:
examples: You need it on full lock (= with the wheel turned as much as possible).

meanings.definition: a way of holding someone that you are fighting against so that they cannot move:
examples: The smaller wrestler held his opponent in a full body lock.

meanings.definition: a rugby player who plays in the second row of the scrum (= a group of players from each team who come together with their heads down and their arms joined, and push against each other to get control of the ball), or this position in the team:
examples: The England lock caught four vital lineout throws.
The lock forward was a member of Italy's under-19 World Cup squad.

meanings.definition: to put an object in a safe place and fasten a lock that prevents someone from entering the place, moving the object, etc.:
examples: He locked the confidential documents in his filing cabinet.
I locked my bike to the railings.
You really should lock your bike up or it'll get stolen.

meanings.definition: to fasten something with a key, or be fastened with a key:
examples: Don't forget to lock the door when you go out.
If you shut the door it will lock automatically.

meanings.definition: to become fixed in one position:
examples: I tried to start moving but the wheels had locked.

meanings.definition: a device that keeps something, such as a door or drawer, fastened, usually needing a key to open it
a length of water with gates at either end where the level of water can be changed to allow boats to move between parts of a canal or river that are at different heights
a curl of hair, or a group of hairs
to be or hold something in a position or condition where movement, escape, or change is not possible:
examples: They’re locked in a lawsuit with their former employer.
The cars crashed and the bumpers locked, making it impossible to move.
The bank won’t lock in our mortgage rate.

meanings.definition: If you lock something somewhere, you make it safe by putting it in a special place and fastening it closed with a lock:
examples: He locked the documents in his filing cabinet.

meanings.definition: to lock all the doors and windows of a building when you leave it:
examples: Sandra, will you lock up tonight when you go?
They locked the house up and went away for two months.

meanings.definition: to put someone in a prison or a hospital for people who are mentally ill:
examples: Murderers should be locked up for life.
After what she did, they should lock her up and throw away the key (= lock her up until she dies).

meanings.definition: a small room, used as a prison, usually in a small town, in which criminals can be kept for a short time
a building where objects, especially a car, can be safely kept
to make a building or room safe by locking the door and fastening the windows:
examples: Don't forget to lock up when you leave the house.

meanings.definition: to put someone in prison:
examples: If found guilty, he could be locked up for life.

meanings.definition: an agreement or period of time during which someone cannot get back the money they have invested:
examples: The moment the lock-up ended, the company's founders sold as much stock as they could get away with.
Management were barred from selling shares under the terms of a lock-up agreement until 12 July.
Some eurobonds have a lockup period of 90 days before they can be sold.

meanings.definition: a building used for storing things safely:
examples: He stores the goods in a lock-up he rents near the market.

meanings.definition: to look at someone who is looking at you:
examples: The two men locked eyes, neither wanting to be the first to look away.
She locked eyes with her daughter in the mirror.

meanings.definition: to begin to argue or fight:
examples: The mayor and her deputy locked horns over plans for the new road.

meanings.definition: to pick up a signal and use it to identify where something is:
examples: It takes a little while for the GPS to lock on.
A device on top of the helicopter prevents heat-seeking missiles locking on.
Smart bombs lock on to targets and guide themselves to the target.
A device in a person's home locks on to the signal emitted by the ankle bracelet during certain times of the day.

meanings.definition: to fasten yourself to something such as a gate or building using a lock, as a form of protest:
examples: Protesters who lock on or obstruct infrastructure have been criminalized by the new law.
They were carrying bicycle locks which they intended to use to lock on.

meanings.definition: a protest that involves fastening yourself to something such as a gate or building using a lock:
examples: Protesters sometimes attempt lock-ons or sit-down protests.
If you do a lock-on, you will probably be arrested.

meanings.definition: the act of picking up a signal and using it to identify where something is:
examples: When you get a lock-on, fire the weapon.
NASA said that if they didn't get radar lock-on by 10,000 feet, they would abort.

meanings.definition: used for keeping a device permanently switched on or keeping it operating in the same way:
examples: The sander has a lock-on switch for continuous use.
A lock-on button keeps the saw cutting at the desired speed.

meanings.definition: used for fastening something firmly to another thing:
examples: Special lock-on clips are provided to keep the shelves in place.

meanings.definition: to prevent a person or organization from ending or changing an agreement or financial arrangement:
examples: The gas company is locked into long-term supply contracts.

meanings.definition: to prevent a person or organization from leaving a legal or financial agreement:
examples: The gas company is locked into long-term supply contracts.
Be careful not to lock yourself into a pile of financial commitments and a salary that only rises once a year.

meanings.definition: to prevent someone from entering a building or room by locking the door:
examples: He had to break into the house because his girlfriend had locked him out.

meanings.definition: to prevent workers from entering their place of work until they agree to particular conditions given by the employer:
examples: Management has threatened to lock out the workforce if they do not accept the proposed changes in working methods.

meanings.definition: to make it impossible for someone to use a computer system, electronic device, etc.:
examples: When someone is fired they are immediately locked out of the network.
If you enter the wrong password too many times, the phone locks you out.
Some parts of the system are locked out so they can't be accessed by mistake.

meanings.definition: to prevent someone from getting into a building, room, or vehicle:
examples: I forgot that my dad didn't have keys, and I locked him out of the house.
The door slammed and our keys were inside – so we were locked out (= unable to get in).

meanings.definition: to prevent a person or organization from having or being able to take part in something:
examples: The company risks being locked out of China's booming car market.

meanings.definition: to prevent a person or organization from having a particular advantage, such as a low price for something:
examples: The company risks being locked out of China's booming car market.
Earn better yields today without locking yourself out of even higher ones next year.

meanings.definition: to put something in a safe place and lock the door in order that someone else cannot get it:
examples: If you keep valuables in your house, lock them away somewhere safe.

meanings.definition: to put money in a place where it is not available to you for a long period:
examples: We asked three financial advisers what they would recommend for someone who is prepared to lock the money away for 10 to 15 years.
Bonds lock money away for between one and five years but tend to pay higher rates of interest than instant-access accounts.

meanings.definition: to get and keep an advantage such as a low price:
examples: People are jumping to purchase homes and lock in affordable mortgage rates before they increase.
If you find a rate that works for you, lock it in.
With the purchase plan, customers would take a daily price and lock it in for a certain number of gallons that have to be bought over a certain time period.

meanings.definition: to choose or decide something finally and definitely, for example by pressing a key on a computer keyboard:
examples: Press SET again to lock in your choice.
He locked in the answer and won $20,000.

meanings.definition: to prevent someone from leaving a room or building by locking the door:
examples: She stormed off to her bedroom and locked herself in.

meanings.definition: to prevent someone from ending or changing a financial arrangement:
examples: Most cell phone contracts lock you in for a fixed period.

meanings.definition: a length of time during which you are not allowed to end or change a financial arrangement:
examples: Your new mortgage may have a long lock-in period, particularly if you go for a fixed rate.

meanings.definition: an occasion when a pub locks its doors and allows people to continue drinking illegally after the time when it should have closed:
examples: There was a lock-in at my local last night.

meanings.definition: to get and keep an advantage such as a low price for something:
examples: People are rushing to purchase homes and lock in affordable mortgage rates before they increase.

meanings.definition: a length of time during which you are not allowed to end a financial agreement:
examples: Your new mortgage may have a long lock-in period.

meanings.definition: to look at someone or something, especially deliberately or for a long time:
examples: Alice locked her eyes on Paul and studied him.

meanings.definition: including all or every part of something:
examples: We had to move our things lock, stock, and barrel to the other side of the country.

meanings.definition: including everything:
examples: I'm selling my house, lock, stock, and barrel with all the furniture and appliances.

meanings.definition: a person who controls a lock (= a body of water with gates) by opening or closing its gates
that can be locked:
examples: All our suitcases are lockable.

meanings.definition: a small box with a button or dials (= moving parts) that allow you to enter a particular series of numbers in order to open the box and get the keys kept inside it:
examples: A lockbox gives agents access to your house key so they can show your home any time a buyer wants to see it.

meanings.definition: any box that can be locked shut:

The Maine Coon is a breed of longhair cat.

meanings.definition: a type of dog that has long hair:
examples: I've had a few bird dogs, but I like longhairs the best.
The shampoo is suitable for longhair dogs.

meanings.definition: used to refer to someone who is well educated and interested in studying and other activities that involve careful thinking and mental effort:
examples: He hated longhairs and wasn't happy when one of his books was well reviewed in The Times.
Eggheads, nerds, bookworms and longhairs have been mocked and dismissed throughout history.

meanings.definition: someone, especially a musician or music fan, with long hair:
examples: A generation of 1960s longhairs headed off to India for extended holidays.
His band of bearded longhairs had the crowd headbanging in no time.

meanings.definition: ordinary writing by hand
writing done by hand usually with a pen or pencil:
examples: He wrote the confession in longhand and signed it.

meanings.definition: a cow from a breed with long horns
a long house where many families live together
a feeling of wanting something or someone very much:
examples: He gazed at her, his eyes full of longing.
a longing look
a longing for his homeland

meanings.definition: a strong desire:
examples: a longing for peace and quiet

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to the feeling of wanting something or someone very much:
examples: She gazed longingly at the box of chocolates.
We passed olive trees, staring longingly at their cool shade.

meanings.definition: quite long
a Latin word meaning "longest", used in medical names and descriptions
the distance of a place east or west of an imaginary line between the North Pole and the South Pole, measured in degrees
the position to the east or west of an imaginary circle around the earth that goes through the North Pole, the South Pole, and Greenwich, England
used to refer to lines or distances east or west of an imaginary line between the North Pole and the South Pole :
examples: Longitudinal lines run from north to south.

meanings.definition: in the long direction of the body or of any body part:
examples: a longitudinal rash

meanings.definition: Longitudinal research is done on people or groups over a long period of time:
examples: longitudinal analysis/studies

meanings.definition: lengthwise:
examples: a longitudinal section

meanings.definition: examined or done over time:
examples: a longitudinal study of mental health

meanings.definition: Longitudinal also means relating to longitude.
a wave moving in the same direction of travel as the vibrations (= fast movements backwards and forwards) of the particles of the substance through which it is travelling
a wave in which the substance the wave travels through moves in the same direction of the wave itself. Sound waves are longitudinal waves.
a Latin word meaning "lengthwise" (= in the direction of the longest side), used in medical names and descriptions
If research is done on people or groups longitudinally, it is done over a long period of time:
examples: Data are from a general population studied longitudinally between the ages of 10 and 36.
Studies that have examined this question longitudinally provide conflicting results.

meanings.definition: in the long direction of the body, or of any body part:
examples: The colon was opened longitudinally and cleaned with water.
The spread occurs longitudinally and is not visible to the surgeon.

meanings.definition: in the direction of the longest side of an object:
examples: Slice the narrow end of the aubergine into several round slices, then slice the rest longitudinally.
The rear seat was longitudinally adjustable.

meanings.definition: an evergreen tree (= one that never loses its leaves) that has long leaves like needles and grows mainly in the southeastern US:
examples: Native species such as longleaf pine survived the hurricane much better than species planted primarily for logging.
The property includes one of the last remaining examples of a longleaf pine forest.

meanings.definition: a list of people, books, etc. being considered for a prize from which a shortlist (= a shorter list of those judged the most suitable) will be chosen:
examples: Only two small publishers are on the longlist this year.
The longlist will be whittled down to four.

meanings.definition: to include a person, book, piece of music, etc. on a longlist:
examples: His first novel was longlisted for the Man Booker Prize.
Longlisted charities will be contacted and asked to submit supplementary material.

meanings.definition: a type of beer bottle with a long, fairly thin neck:
examples: They stick slices of lime into the longneck bottles.
The spicy hot potatoes are the perfect complement for an ice-cold long-neck.

meanings.definition: UK government bonds that will be paid back more than 15 years in the future:
examples: Switching the debt into longer-term paper would boost the supply of longs and push down prices.
LIFFE's futures contract for long gilts is one of the ten most heavily traded contracts in the world.

meanings.definition: shares, bonds, etc. that an investor is keeping and planning to sell at a profit when the price rises:
examples: The stock moved up and down sharply as a tug-of-war game was played out between the shorts and the longs.

meanings.definition: a long and narrow ship with one square sail (= sheet of material attached to a pole to catch the wind and make the ship move) and many oars (= long poles with a wide, flat part at one end, used for moving a boat), used by the Viking people:
examples: It was too small for a Viking longship, but not sufficiently decorated to be the ship of a king.
Vikings set out on longships from Scandinavia, and ended up in places like Scotland and Ireland.

meanings.definition: Longshore workers work at a port, especially putting goods onto and taking them off ships:
examples: Longshore workers continued loading and unloading the ships.
A typical longshore gang ranges from 12 to 20 workers.

meanings.definition: parallel with or at an angle to the coast:
examples: Such waves pile water up and initiate longshore currents.

meanings.definition: the movement of sand and small stones, etc. along the coast by waves travelling parallel or at an angle to the coast
a person who works at a port, putting goods onto and taking them off ships
a person whose job is loading and unloading ships
someone whose job is putting goods onto and taking goods off ships in a port
having good judgment about what will happen in the future and the ability to make wise decisions based on this:
examples: His foreign policy was a combination of longsighted achievements and short-sighted blunders.
They showed themselves to be broad-minded, mature, and long-sighted.

meanings.definition: A longsighted person can only clearly see objects that are far away:
examples: Convex lenses help those who are longsighted; concave lenses those who are short-sighted.
Long-sighted people are unable to see close objects clearly.

meanings.definition: good judgment about what will be needed in the future and the ability to make wise decisions based on this:
examples: The partners have both entrepreneurial spirit and longsightedness.
It was with long-sightedness and determination that he reached his goals.

meanings.definition: the conditon of only being able to clearly see things that are far away from you:
examples: Thousands of people suffer from longsightedness.
Eyeglasses with convex lenses are prescribed for long-sightedness.

meanings.definition: having existed or lasted for many years:
examples: a longtime friend

meanings.definition: a boring part of something, especially a book, film, etc.:
examples: Despite the occasional longueurs, this is an impressive first novel.

meanings.definition: a Latin word meaning "long", used in the medical names and descriptions of some muscles
along the length:
examples: Fold the paper longways.

meanings.definition: informal for toilet:
examples: I'll just go to the loo.
loo roll

meanings.definition: an object with a rough surface that is used to rub the body when washing. Loofahs are made from the dried fruit of a tropical plant, also called a loofah.

meanings.definition: to think about what will happen in the future and plan for these events:

meanings.definition: a series of instructions that is repeated until a particular thing happens:
examples: The CPU world relies upon condition variables, branches, and loops.

meanings.word_type: verb[ I or T,  usually + adv/prep ]
meanings.definition: to make a loop or curve:
examples: Loop the rope over the bar.
Turn left where the road loops round the farm buildings.

meanings.word_type: verb[ I or T,  usually + adv/prep ]
meanings.definition: (of a short piece of recorded music) to be repeated all through a song or part of a song:
examples: The sample is automatically looped to repeat continuously until you tell it to stop.

meanings.definition: a circular shape made by something long and narrow in which the two ends cross each other, leaving an open space within:
examples: A loop of thread from my sweater caught on a nail.
The exit ramp makes a loop under the elevated highway.

meanings.definition: one or more instructions given repeatedly by a computer program until a particular result is achieved
a small U-shaped tube that is part of a nephron (= a structure that collects water and salt from urine) in the kidney:
examples: The loop of Henle allows water to be conserved in the body, rather than lost in urine.
In humans, about 14% of the loops of Henle are long and reach down into the medulla of the kidney.

meanings.definition: to move in the shape of a vertical circle, for example in a plane or on a rollercoaster (= a ride in an amusement park, that goes up and down very steep slopes and around very sudden bends):
examples: He decided to learn to fly, and before too long he was looping the loop high over Texas.
On this ride, you loop-the-loop seven times.
The male birds perform aerobatics, looping the loop and spinning through 360 degrees.
"Hold on, we're gonna loop-de-loop now," he said.

meanings.definition: (of someone's heart) to seem to make a big sudden movement because of a strong feeling:
examples: Mary's heart looped the loop when Tom asked her out to dinner.

meanings.definition: a movement in the shape of a vertical circle, for example by a plane or a rollercoaster (= a ride in an amusement park, that goes up and down very steep slopes and around very sudden bends):
examples: As we looked up, the plane started doing a loop-the-loop.
A large tornado appears to be doing a loop the loop and is moving south west.
Katherine Stinson was the first woman in the world to perform the loop-the-loop, in 1915.
Birds were doing loop-de-loops in the sky.

meanings.definition: the feeling of your heart seeming to make a sudden big movement because of a strong feeling:
examples: He makes my heart do a loop-the-loop every time I see him.

meanings.definition: A loop-the-loop rollercoaster (= a ride in an amusement park, that goes up and down very steep slopes and around very sudden bends) includes vertical circles:
examples: The more adventurous can enjoy rides like the loop-the-loop rollercoaster or water chute.
The loop-the-loop ride might feel very dangerous but it isn't really.

meanings.definition: moving in a vertical circle in the sky:
examples: A fruit fly can execute dazzling loop-the-loop manoeuvres.

meanings.definition: a small mistake in an agreement or law that gives someone the chance to avoid having to do something:
examples: tax loopholes
The company employed lawyers to find loopholes in environmental protection laws.

meanings.definition: an opportunity to legally avoid an unpleasant responsibility, usually because of a mistake in the way rules or laws have been written:
examples: The new law is designed to close most of the tax loopholes.

meanings.definition: a failure to include something in an agreement or law, which allows someone to do something illegal or to avoid doing something:
examples: They plan to close a loophole that allows businesses to avoid paying off redundant workers.
He has pledged to close a tax loophole that has allowed US firms to take business and jobs abroad.
Determined landlords found it easy to exploit loopholes in the law.

meanings.definition: in a strange, unusual, or silly way:
examples: This ridiculously silly musical version of the film is loopily enjoyable.
The dog ran loopily around the room, approaching all the guests and begging for food.
