meanings.definition: strange, unusual, or silly:
examples: He must have gone completely loopy to give up a job like that.

meanings.definition: not firmly held or fastened in place:
examples: There were some loose wires hanging out of the wall.
The nails in the wall had worked themselves loose.
The prisoners were so thin that their skin hung loose.

meanings.definition: Loose hair is not tied back:
examples: Her hair was hanging loose to her shoulders.

meanings.definition: Loose things are not held together or attached to anything else:
examples: A few loose sheets of paper were lying around.

meanings.definition: (of clothes) not fitting closely to the body:
examples: Wear comfortable, loose clothing to your exercise class.

meanings.definition: not tightly controlled, or not exact:
examples: It's a fairly loose adaptation of the novel.
It's only a loose translation of the poem.

meanings.definition: having low morals; sexually free:
examples: a loose woman

meanings.definition: to speak or express emotions very freely, especially in an uncontrolled way:
examples: The coach loosed an angry tirade against his team.
He loosed his frustration in a torrent of abuse.

meanings.definition: to fire an arrow from a bow or shots from a gun:
examples: They were almost upon us as I loosed my last arrow.
His men loosed a volley of rifle fire into the surviving guards.

meanings.definition: to allow something harmful or extreme to happen and affect somewhere:
examples: Sometimes anarchy is loosed upon the world because people firmly and honestly believe they are doing the right thing.

meanings.definition: to set an animal free, especially in order to attack someone:
examples: They basically loosed the hounds on us.

meanings.definition: to make something such as a knot or tie less tight:
examples: She loosed the knot and undid the bright coil of my hair.
The two hundred miles an hour wind had loosed the chains.

meanings.definition: not firmly attached in place:
examples: I’d better sew that loose button before it comes off.
A few loose sheets of paper were lying around.

meanings.definition: If an animal is loose, it is not tied up or caged in.
not tight; not fitting closely to the body or the thing that is covered:
examples: Wear comfortable, loose clothing to your exercise class.

meanings.definition: Loose can also mean not closely following something original, or not exact:
examples: The film is a loose adaptation of Conrad’s novel.

meanings.definition: not tightly held together or to anything else:
examples: According to research, sales of tea bags, loose tea and instant tea have all declined.

meanings.definition: in some sports, a ball that is not being held or controlled by a player, but that can be picked up and moved by a player on either team:
examples: In American football, you cannot kick a loose ball on purpose to keep it away from another player, or else you will get a penalty.
If a loose ball goes out of bounds, it belongs to the last team that had possession of it.

meanings.definition: someone who behaves in an uncontrolled or unexpected way and is likely to cause problems for other people:
examples: He's seen as something of a loose cannon by other team members.
I don't think we can take a risk on a loose cannon like him running our country.

meanings.definition: the coins that you have in your pocket or purse
the coins that you carry with you:
examples: Carry some loose change to make emergency public telephone calls.
In the world of big business, £20m is little more than loose change.

meanings.definition: covers on a chair or sofa that you can remove for cleaning
something that still needs to be done or explained:
examples: My research is done, but I have some loose ends to tie up.

meanings.definition: things that still need to be done or explained:
examples: At the end of the book all the loose ends are neatly tied up.

meanings.definition: a rugby player who plays at the back of the scrum (= a group of players from each team who come together with their heads down and arms joined, and push against each other to get control of the ball), or this position in a team:
examples: The 19-year-old loose forward was a key figure in the team's triumph earlier this month.
He's sticking to his favourite position of loose forward.

meanings.definition: tea in the form of dried tea leaves that have not been put into teabags (= small paper bags each filled with enough tea leaves to make tea for one person):
examples: She didn't use teabags, but brewed a pot using loose tea.

meanings.definition: to decide to control a person or situation less:
examples: Sooner or later Isambard would have to loose his hold of him.
The main insurgent objective was to loose America's grip on the Persian Gulf.

meanings.definition: Loose-fitting clothing is quite large and does not fit tightly:
examples: a loose-fitting shirt

meanings.definition: A loose-jointed person moves and bends their body, especially their arms and legs, very easily:
examples: He moves with loose-jointed athleticism.
She set off toward them with a long, loose-jointed stride.

meanings.definition: A loose-jointed story does not have a very ordered structure:
examples: It's a loose-jointed, coming-of-age story set in Australia.
The story he tells is a loose-jointed fable.

meanings.definition: having pages that can easily be taken out and put back again:
examples: a loose-leaf binder

meanings.definition: having special paper that can be easily removed and replaced:
examples: a loose-leaf notebook

meanings.definition: containing pages that can easily be taken out and put back again:
examples: a loose-leaf binder/folder/notebook

meanings.definition: in a way that is not firmly held or attached:

meanings.definition: not exactly:
examples: This phrase can be loosely translated as "Go away!"
The film is loosely based on the novel by Kundera.

meanings.definition: not tightly:
examples: The jacket hung loosely on his thin body.

meanings.definition: not tightly; not in a way that fits closely to the body or the thing that is covered:
examples: The package was loosely wrapped.

meanings.definition: not put together tightly; with spaces between the parts that form a structure:
examples: a loosely knit sweater

meanings.definition: to (cause to) become loose:
examples: The screws holding the bed together had loosened.

meanings.definition: to make something such as your hair or a piece of clothing less tight:
examples: He loosened his tie.

meanings.definition: to become or make something less firmly fixed:
examples: The screws holding the light fixture have loosened, and it’s dangling from the ceiling.
fig. When immigration laws were loosened, the number of immigrants shot up.

meanings.definition: to prepare your muscles for a physical activity by stretching and doing simple exercises:
examples: I do a few stretches to loosen up before I run.

meanings.definition: to start to feel less embarrassed and to become more relaxed when you are with other people, or to make someone feel like this:
examples: He seemed quite nervous at the beginning, but he soon loosened up.
A gin and tonic will loosen you up.

meanings.definition: to make someone speak more freely:
examples: A couple of glasses of champagne had loosened my tongue and I said things that perhaps I shouldn't have.

meanings.definition: If you loosen your grip on an object, or your grip loosens, you hold something less tightly:
examples: He held my hand very tightly at first but gradually his grip loosened.

meanings.definition: If you loosen your grip/hold on a situation, or your grip/hold loosens, you decide to control it less:
examples: The dictator's grip on the country has not loosened.

meanings.definition: one of a number of different plants, some with tall purple or yellow flowers, that grow wild and in gardens. Some types cause problems in areas where they do not grow naturally:
examples: Native flowers are being out-competed by purple loosestrife.
One good thing about loosestrife is they attract butterflies.

meanings.definition: comfortable and relaxed:

The movie is aiming for the loosey-goosey chaos of the old Looney Tunes cartoons.

meanings.definition: not careful, accurate, or exact enough, or not tightly controlled :
examples: This idea is way too loosey-goosey to get past a curriculum committee.
We can tackle the problem, as long as we don't have that loosey-goosey regulation that we had in the past.

meanings.definition: (usually of large numbers of people during a violent event) to steal from shops and houses:
examples: During the riot shops were looted and cars damaged or set on fire.

meanings.definition: to steal something from a place or person:
examples: Burglars looted cash and mobiles from a shop in Tagore Town.
The passengers in the general compartment of Shramjivi Express were looted and robbed of their valuables.

meanings.definition: money and valuable objects that have been stolen, especially by an army from a defeated enemy or by thieves:
examples: The thief must have been very disappointed when he examined his loot.
He was captured and his loot was returned to the store.

meanings.definition: in computer games, the things you get as rewards, for example for defeating an enemy, that you can use in the games:
examples: It provides the same experiences as larger dungeon games: fighting monsters, disarming traps, advancing characters, and collecting loot.
Enjoy this free online adventure game - battle demons with your friends, earn loot and build the ultimate castle!

meanings.definition: (said esp. of large numbers of people) to steal from stores:
examples: Riot police were sent to prevent the mob from looting.

meanings.definition: To loot something is also to take a lot of money away from it that does not belong to you:
examples: The officers of the corporation looted the company of millions of dollars.

meanings.definition: money or valuable objects that have been stolen:
examples: Three men have been sentenced to prison for taking part in the robbery, but the loot was never recovered.

meanings.definition: money or valuable objects that have been stolen:
examples: They hauled the loot, worth $10 million, to a warehouse.

meanings.definition: in computer games, a container with a selection of things inside that can be used when playing the game. You can buy loot boxes with real or game money and you do not usually know what is inside until you open it:
examples: Loot boxes allow players to spend money to unlock in-game rewards, such as special characters, weapons or outfits, without knowing what they will get.
When the gamer buys a loot crate, they are guaranteed something they can use in the game.

meanings.definition: someone who steals something from a place or person:

meanings.definition: the activity of stealing from shops during a violent event:
examples: There were reports of widespread looting as hooligans stampeded through the city centre.

meanings.definition: to cut a piece from something with a single quick action:
examples: We’ve got to lop off the lower branches of this tree.
fig. The city council lopped thousands of dollars from the budget.

meanings.definition: to cut something off in one quick movement:
examples: I'll need to lop off the lower branches of the tree.

meanings.definition: to reduce a price or the amount of time taken to do something by a particular amount:
examples: He lopped eight seconds off the record.

meanings.definition: (of a person or animal) to run taking long, relaxed steps:
examples: The lion loped across the grass.

meanings.definition: a way of walking or moving using long, relaxed steps:
examples: The trot quickly became a lope, which just as quickly became a gallop.
She crossed the field with the easy lope of a woman half her age.

meanings.definition: with one side bigger, higher, etc. than the other:
examples: He had a charming, lopsided grin.
The desk was scratched and lopsided; a thick book had been wedged underneath its short leg.

meanings.definition: not equally balanced in amount, importance, etc.:
examples: The lopsided vote demonstrates how isolated the minister has become.
The comparison is not as lopsided as it seems at first.

meanings.definition: with one side or part much bigger or higher than the other; uneven:
examples: The Yankees won by the lopsided score of 17 to 2.

meanings.definition: in a way that has one side bigger, higher, etc. than the other:
examples: I grinned lopsidedly and asked her if she wanted a drink.
His lopsidedly handsome face looked tense.

meanings.definition: in a way that is not equally balanced:
examples: In the last election, 45 percent of Americans lived in counties that were lopsidedly Republican or Democratic.
Some children are lopsidedly gifted, with very strong interests in one direction.

meanings.definition: the fact of having one side bigger, higher, etc. than the other:
examples: The doctor decided to operate again to try to correct the lopsidedness of his face.
I am curious to see if the tree can cure its own lopsidedness.

meanings.definition: the fact of not being equally balanced in amount, importance, etc.:
examples: Despite the lopsidedness of the defeat, he said he doesn't feel too bad.
The lopsidedness is further reinforced by the huge weight of one company, which accounts for almost half the total market.

meanings.definition: Someone who is loquacious talks a lot.
having the habit of talking a lot
in a loquacious way (= talking a lot):
examples: He was loquaciously charming.
They expounded loquaciously on every issue, as though they'd been rehearsing for weeks.

meanings.definition: the fact of talking a lot:
examples: Despite his loquacity, he had a lot of secrets.

meanings.definition: a tree that does not lose its leaves in winter, originally from East Asia, with flowers that appear in the autumn:
examples: These loquats are purely decorative and rarely bear fruit.
He counted the fruit on the loquat tree every day.

meanings.definition: the small, round fruit of this tree with a thin, smooth, yellow-orange skin, similar to a plum:
examples: Loquats can be eaten fresh, in salads, or cooked in meat dishes.
The small loquats sweeten as they ripen.

meanings.definition: a male peer
a man who has a lot of power in a particular area of activity:
examples: Several alleged drug lords are to be put on trial.

meanings.definition: a title used in front of the names of male peers and officials of very high rank:
examples: Lord Longford
the Lord Chancellor

meanings.definition: (in the Christian religion) God or Jesus Christ:
examples: Praise the Lord!
Lord, hear our prayer.

meanings.definition: (in some countries) a title of a man who has a specially high social rank, or the person himself
A lord is also a man who has a lot of power in a particular area:
examples: a feudal lord
a crime lord

meanings.definition: (in the Christian and Jewish religions) God
Some people say Lord to express surprise, shock, or worry:
examples: Oh Lord! I’ve forgotten the tickets!

meanings.definition: to behave as if you are more important than someone and have a right to tell that person what to do:
examples: He likes to lord it over his little sister.

meanings.definition: used to say that you do not know:
examples: Lord knows where we're going to get the money from.

meanings.definition: If you are lord, master, mistress, king, or queen of all you survey, you own or control the place in which you live or work.
used to decribe someone who behaves as if they are better than other people:
examples: a lordly air

meanings.definition: a condition in which someone's spine (= the line of bones down their back) curves inwards too much

a plant that grows in woods, with shiny, pointed leaves, a central pointed part, and a large, pointed, pale green outer part. Its orange-red berries grow close together on the central part and are very poisonous. :
examples: The leaves of lords-and-ladies were unrolling on the riverbank.
Starch used for laundry was obtained from the roots of lords-and-ladies.

meanings.definition: used to express surprise, shock, or worry or to emphasize something:
examples: Lordy, you should have heard the noise!

meanings.definition: traditional knowledge and stories about a subject:
examples: According to local lore, the water has healing properties.
A lot of cultural lore surrounds the apple.

meanings.definition: background information about the fictional (= invented) characters in a book, film, computer game, etc. and the fictional place and situation in which its events happen that is accepted as true by its fans (= people who are very enthusiastic about something and like to write or talk about it):
examples: There are alternate takes on the lore of the World of Warcraft.
If you are a hardcore Tolkien lore fan, you will find this information surprising.

meanings.definition: knowledge and stories, usually traditional, about a subject:
examples: He published several books on Indian lore and hunting.

meanings.definition: a very old-fashioned pair of glasses with a long handle that you hold in front of your eyes
a small, brightly coloured parrot found in Australia and Southeast Asia

a small primate (= a member of the most developed and intelligent group of mammals) that lives in trees in the forests of south and southeast Asia and is active at night. There are several species (= types) of loris:
examples: The loris is a shy, nocturnal primate with huge eyes.

meanings.definition: alone and unhappy; left alone and not cared for
an account that one bank holds for another bank, usually one in another country

a 
        
         truck  :
examples: an articulated lorry
a long-distance lorry driver

meanings.definition: truck
a large road vehicle that is used for transporting goods:
examples: The stock is delivered by lorry from the huge warehouses.
The company has a fleet of trucks supplying wholesalers and retailers.
a lorry driver
a container/delivery/refrigerated lorry

meanings.definition: the largest city in the western US state of California and a centre of the entertainment industry:
examples: Los Angeles is expected to have more rain tomorrow.
I have a friend in Los Angeles.

meanings.definition: to no longer have something because you do not know where it is:
examples: I've lost my ticket.
He's always losing his car keys.

meanings.definition: to have something or someone taken away from you:
examples: At least 600 staff will lose their jobs if the factory closes.
He lost his leg in a car accident.
She lost her mother (= her mother died) last year.

meanings.definition: to stop feeling something:
examples: to lose confidence/faith
I lost interest halfway through the book.
He kept on crying and I lost my patience.

meanings.definition: to have less of something than you had before:
examples: I'm trying to lose weight.
He's losing his hair.
She lost a lot of blood in the accident.
to lose your memory/sight

meanings.definition: If you lose time, you waste it:
examples: Four million hours were lost last year through stress-related illnesses.
We lost valuable time stuck in traffic.

meanings.definition: If a clock loses time, it goes more slowly than it should:
examples: My watch loses ten minutes every day.

meanings.definition: to get rid of something:
examples: Lose the belt and let's see how the dress looks.

meanings.definition: to fail to succeed in a game, competition, etc.:
examples: If we lose this game, we're out of the championship.
They're losing 3–1.
They lost to Cincinnati.
Everyone hates losing an argument.
They hadn't lost an election in 15 years.

meanings.definition: to not be able to find something:
examples: I lost my keys somewhere in the house.
Two officers chased the suspect, but he turned down an alley and they lost sight of him (= could no longer see him).

meanings.definition: to no longer have something, because it has been taken away from you, either by accident or purposely:
examples: Workers will lose their jobs if the plant closes.
He lost his leg in a car accident.

meanings.definition: If you lose someone, that person dies:
examples: George lost his wife in 1990.

meanings.definition: If you lose money you have risked, you do not make a profit and do not get your money back.
A business that is losing money is spending more money than it is receiving.
to fail to succeed in a game or competition:
examples: If we lose again, we’re out of the playoffs.
Anderson lost the election by a narrow margin.

meanings.definition: to not maintain or no longer have control over a quality or ability:
examples: She used to play tennis regularly, but lately she’s lost interest in it.
The driver lost control of her car.
The dog is losing her eyesight/hearing/sense of smell.
Carl lost his balance and fell down the stairs.

meanings.definition: If you lose time or an opportunity, you waste it.
If a clock loses time, it goes more slowly than it should.
to have less of something, esp. in the body:
examples: to lose blood/weight

meanings.definition: to confuse someone:
examples: I’m sorry, you’ve lost me – would you go over that again?

meanings.definition: to no longer have something or have less of something, because it has been taken away from you, or you fail to keep it:
examples: Manufacturing lost 11,000 jobs in June after several months of small increases.
She was among 40 people who lost their jobs when the plant closed.
The company has steadily lost market share over the past 15 years.
The company has lost its place as the world's number one automaker.
Last year, the company lost at least 30 working days to strikes.
The business began to lose clients to the new supermarket.
The organization has lost the finest director it has ever had.
Homeowners technically could still lose their homes over unpaid rent.

meanings.definition: if you lose time, you waste it:
examples: Four million working hours were lost last year through stress-related illnesses.
There is no time to be lost in securing the deal.

meanings.definition: to spend more money than you receive, fail to keep money that you had, or cause a loss of money:
examples: The airline lost £40m from a strike at the airport in the summer.
Companies must compensate employees who lose financially because of a misleading, inaccurate, or unfair reference.
We cannot continue with an area of business that is losing us millions.
He lost $50000 on the stock market.

meanings.definition: to go down in price or value:

meanings.definition: the quality of being pleasantly thick or full:
examples: His long hair has a voluminous luxuriance.

meanings.definition: growing thickly, strongly, and well:
examples: Tall, luxuriant plants grew along the river bank.

meanings.definition: pleasantly thick or full:

meanings.definition: having a thick and healthy appearance:

meanings.definition: (usually of plants or hair) in a way that grows thickly, strongly, and well:
examples: The park is luxuriantly full of vegetation.

meanings.definition: in a way that is pleasantly thick or full:
examples: He had the most beautiful, luxuriantly long eyelashes.

meanings.definition: to get great pleasure from something, especially because it provides physical comfort:
examples: There's nothing better after a hard day's work than to luxuriate in a hot bath.

meanings.definition: very comfortable and expensive:
examples: They have a very luxurious house.

meanings.definition: giving great pleasure:

meanings.definition: in a very comfortable and expensive way:

meanings.definition: in a way that gives great pleasure:

meanings.definition: great comfort, especially as provided by expensive and beautiful things:
examples: to live in luxury
a luxury cruise
a luxury hotel

meanings.definition: something expensive that is pleasant to have but is not necessary:
examples: luxuries, such as champagne and chocolate

meanings.definition: something that gives you a lot of pleasure but cannot be done often:
examples: A day off work is such a luxury.

meanings.definition: great comfort, esp. as provided by expensive and beautiful possessions, surroundings, or food, or something enjoyable and often expensive but not necessary:
examples: a life of luxury
a luxury hotel
Having an extra bathroom was at first a luxury, but after we had children it became a necessity.

meanings.definition: A luxury is also any unusual, enjoyable activity:
examples: Sleeping late was a real luxury.

meanings.definition: the pleasure and comfort you get from expensive and beautiful things:
examples: I made money on shares and for a while I lived in luxury.

meanings.definition: something expensive which is pleasant to have but is not really necessary:
examples: He enjoys luxuries, such as champagne and caviar.

meanings.definition: something that gives you pleasure or an advantage which you do not usually have:
examples: A day off work is such a luxury.

meanings.definition: an expensive product or service provided by a particular company that has a reputation for being of high quality:

meanings.definition: expensive things, such as jewellery and make-up, that are pleasant to have but are not necessary:
examples: The government will pay for the new schools by increasing the tax on luxury goods.

meanings.definition: a market for expensive goods that are not necessary but are bought for pleasure:

meanings.definition: a tax on expensive goods that are not necessary but are bought for pleasure:
